questions.text: Which of the following has a role in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Rifaximin has a role in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy.

The mainstay of treatment of hepatic encephalopathy is the use of lactulose. Lactulose is a non-absorbable disaccharide that is catabolized by the colonic flora into acidic compounds, thus reducing the colonic pH to acidic. This reduction in pH leads to the formation of non-absorbable NH4+ from NH3, thus reducing the plasma ammonia levels. Lactulose also increases the hyperosmolar load on the colon, improving gastrointestinal transit and reducing the time for ammonia reabsorption.

Adjunctive therapy for hepatic encephalopathy includes the administration of antibiotics with poor systemic absorption. Rifaximin reduces the recurrences of encephalopathy episodes in patients with cirrhosis.

There is no role of protein restriction in the treatment of encephalopathy because of the overall negative effect of this step on the nutritional status of the patient.

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient presents to you with complaints of pain and inability to do pinching activities, after suffering a fall on an outstretched hand while practicing skiing for the winter sports events. Which of the following structure is usually injured in the given scenario? (DIP- distal interphalangeal joints)

choices.text: Injury to extensor tendon at DIP
Injury to flexor tendon at DIP

questions.solution:
Clinical history of a Skier falling on an outstretched hand, after which pinching activities are affected, is suggestive of Gamekeeper’s thumb/Skier's thumb. It involves injury to Ulnar collateral ligament.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction. Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint. Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

In a partial rupture:

  • Only the ligament is torn and the thumb is unstable only in flexion 
  • The volar plate is intact, keeping the thumb stable in extension

In a complete rupture:

  • Both the ligament and the volar plate are torn 
  • The thumb is unstable in all positions

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: According to WHO's SAFE strategy to control trachoma, what is the recommended management in an area where the prevalence of trachoma in children aged 1-9 years is between 5% to 10%?

choices.text: Targeted antibiotic therapy of patient, their family members and close contacts
Single dose mass antibiotic therapy at the community level
Treatment of the affected patients alone, diagnosed via community camps
Annual mass antibiotic therapy at community level for three years

questions.solution:
In areas with a prevalence between more than 5% and less than 10%, targeted antibiotic therapy is recommended only among family members and close contacts of the patients according to WHO's SAFE strategy to control trachoma. 

Trachoma is chronic keratoconjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is one of the leading causes of preventable blindness in the world. Features are foreign body sensation, lacrimation, mucoid discharge etc. On examination, conjunctival follicles resembling boiled sago grains are seen. The follicles if present on the bulbar conjunctiva, is pathognomic. Herbert's follicles may be seen at the limbus. The cornea may get infiltrated and vascularized leading to progressive pannus.

WHO programme for prophylaxis against trachoma infection and prevention of blindness is SAFE strategy. It includes:

  • Surgery - Tertiary prevention.
  • Antibiotic use - Secondary prevention.
  • Facial hygiene - Primary prevention.
  • Environmental changes - Primordial prevention.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the right upper leg associated with pain. His radiographic image is shown below. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which among the following is false?

choices.text: Radioisotope scan would show marked increase in activity
It is mostly seen on femoral or tibial metaphysis
The condition is a form of chronic osteomyelitis
Staphylococcus aureus would mostly be involved

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiographic image showing a lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim are suggestive of Brodie's abscess which is a form of subacute osteomyelitis, not a chronic form.

The patient is usually a child or adolescent, who would present with pain and swelling on the affected limb. The temperature, WBC counts, and blood cultures are usually normal, with sometimes elevated ESR. There is often very little to suggest an infection.

The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity. The organism mostly involved would be staphylococcus aureus.

It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur. The patient presents with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area. A biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) IV for 4-5 days and followed by orally for another 6 weeks. The healing may take up to 12 months.

Curettage is needed if the X-rays show no healing after conservative management.

questions.text: An autopsy of a man who died due to a gunshot was done in which two bullets were found in his body. External examination revealed only one entrance wound. Which of the following mechanisms may help explain this?
questions.solution:
In certain cases, when a bullet fails to expel upon firing, a subsequent shot may cause both the original lodged bullet and the second bullet to enter the body through the same entry point. This phenomenon is referred to as a tandem or piggyback bullet.

The presence of an excess number of bullets compared to the observed entrance wounds can be attributed to factors such as weapon malfunctions, defective ammunition, prolonged non-usage of the loaded firearm, or exposure to extreme environmental conditions like high temperature or humidity. It is possible for the bullets to either separate within the body or before reaching the intended target.

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: A patient is posted for an elective procedure under general anesthesia. Being an intern in the anesthetist's team, you are asked to monitor the bispectral Index. What will be the bispectral index (BIS) reading if the patient is still in a state of sedation and not under adequate general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The range of bispectral index reading if the patient is still in the state of sedation and not under adequate general anesthesia is 65-85.

BIS is a monitoring technique used to check the depth of anesthesia and prevent intraoperative awareness. It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 and 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness. BIS monitors examine four components within the EEG that are associated with the anesthetic state.

  1. Low frequency, as found during deep anesthesia.
  2. High-frequency beta activation, found during light anesthesia.
  3. Suppressed EEG waves.
  4. Burst suppression.

It has numerical values from 0 to 100, with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS. Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for general anesthesia is 40-65.

 BIS 
value		    Interpretation
     80-100    Awake(Respond to normal voice)
     65-85 sedation
     40-65 General anesthesia
      <40  Deep hypnosis(Cortical suppression)
0  Coma (Flatline EEG)

Monitors used to assess the depth of anesthesia are: 

  1. Electroencephalography (EEG)
  2. Bispectral index (BIS)
  3. Entropy
  4. Evoked responses (EP) - Motor EP, sensory EP (Auditory, visual, brain stem evoked potential)
  5. Patient state index
  6. Narcotrend.

questions.text: The suprascapular nerve is the content of which of the following triangles marked in the neck region?
questions.solution:
The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The nerve is a component of the subclavian triangle.

In the given image:

  • A – Carotid triangle
  • B – Occipital triangle 
  • C – Subclavian triangle
  • D – Muscular triangle

Contents of the subclavian triangle are:

  • 3rd part of Subclavian Artery and vein
  • Suprascapular artery and vein, transverse cervical artery
  • Supraclavicular lymph node
  • Trunks of Brachial plexus
  • Nerve to Serratus anterior
  • Branches from upper trunk – N to Subclavius, Suprascapular nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: A low sodium diet decreases the risk of pre-eclampsia
Calcium supplementation in calcium-deficient mothers decreases the risk of preeclampsia
Treatment of preeclampsia with magnesium increases endothelin-1 concentrates
There is decreased vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2

questions.solution:
Calcium supplementation in calcium-deficient mothers decreases the risk of preeclampsia.

Women who have a low daily intake, other calcium-deficient states, or live in an area of endemic calcium deficiency may benefit from calcium supplementation to reduce the risk of preeclampsia

Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia. Unless women are calcium deficient, supplementation has no salutary effects.

A sodium-restricted diet is ineffective in preventing preeclampsia.

Treatment of preeclampsia with magnesium lowers endothelin-1 concentrates. 

There is increased vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding donor twin, in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS )?
questions.solution:
Donor twin is anemic in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a type of fetal syndrome that can arise when monozygotic twinning results in two amnionic sacs and a common surrounding chorion.

This leads to anatomical sharing of the two fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. It depends on the degree to which they are hemodynamically balanced. In those with significant pressure or flow gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic fetofetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

In this syndrome, blood is transfused from a donor twin to its recipient sibling such that the donor may eventually become anemic and its growth may be restricted. In contrast, the recipient becomes polycythemic and may develop circulatory overload manifest as hydrops.

Other features:

Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics
Oliguria Polyuria
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Hypotension Hypertension
Anemia Polycythemia
Renal failure Congestive cardiac failure
Growth restriction Premature rupture of membranes
Pulmonary hypoplasia Hyperbilirubinemia
Contractures  

Note: The donor twin is also known as the pump twin / stuck twin.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding vitamin D synthesis?
  1. Synthesis occurs sequentially in the skin, liver, kidney
  2. Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin
  3. 25 hydroxylase acts in the kidney
  4. 1-α-hydroxylase is present in the liver
questions.solution:
The true statements are statements 1 and 2.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney. Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin. 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis:

Step 1: In the skin: 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream.

Step 2: In the liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol). The enzyme responsible for this is 25 hydroxylase. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3: In the kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to either 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis

  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs has not been found to reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF?

HFrEF: heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, DHP-type calcium channel blockers such as amlodipine have no role in the management of HFrEF and do not reduce mortality due to it. 

Heart failure is a complex clinical syndrome that occurs because the ventricle is unable to fill with or eject blood. The important etiologies of heart failure include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and high output states, such as beriberi, thyrotoxicosis, and severe anaemia.

Patients with heart failure complain of dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. On examination, pedal oedema, elevated JVP, ascites, and hepatomegaly may be present.

Heart failure is termed HFrEF when the EF is below 40%. The pharmacological management of HFrEF includes two broad categories of drugs:

Drugs with symptomatic and mortality benefits reduce mortality in patients by neurohormonal mechanisms and thus prevent cardiac remodelling. These drugs include:

  • Angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI): a combination of sacubitril (neprilysin inhibitor) and valsartan (angiotensin-receptor blocker)
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors: ramipril, enalapril
  • β-blockers: metoprolol, carvedilol, bisoprolol
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist: spironolactone, eplerenone
  • Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2 inhibitor) - dapagliflozin
  • Hydralazine plus isosorbide dinitrate: has shown mortality benefit only in African-American patients

Drugs with symptomatic benefits are used only when there are specific indications for their use or when the patient has decompensation of already existing heart failure.

  • Loop diuretics such furosemide
  • Digoxin

Non-pharmacological therapy for HFrEF includes implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD) and cardiac resynchronization therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral weakness and spasticity of muscle groups.
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation

questions.solution:
A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have an ipsilateral loss of vibration sense.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor. The clinical features are:

  • Damage to the fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus results in the loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception on the same side of the body below the level of the affected area.
  • When the spinothalamic tract is affected, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body, starting one or two segments below the lesion.
  • Injury to the corticospinal tract leads to weakness and spasticity in specific muscle groups on the affected side of the body.
 

 

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Donovan bodies seen on biopsy is a characteristic feature of:
questions.solution:

Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes".

The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining, which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Donovan bodies appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of smoking for the past 30 years is admitted to the ward with cough and shortness of breath. The spirometry result is given below. Which of the following physical finding is unlikely to be associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of smoking for the past 30 years now presenting with cough and shortness of breath, with the spirometry showing an obstructive pattern (coved in appearance of the expiratory limb) suggests chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Clubbing is not a physical finding seen in COPD.

Patients with COPD present with cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion. General physical examination may show cyanosis (option A) in the lips and the nail beds. COPD is also accompanied by severe weight loss due to the loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue (option C). This occurs due to inadequate food intake and high inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α.

On respiratory examination, a prolonged expiratory phase and an expiratory wheeze may be noted. Hyperinflation of the lungs gives rise to the characteristic barrel-shaped chest (option B) seen in these patients. Severe airflow limitation causes the patients to sit in a tripod position to and use the accessory muscles of respiration. 

Clubbing of the digits is not a sign of COPD. Its presence in a chronic smoker with COPD most commonly indicates the development of lung cancer in such a patient.

questions.text: A first-year medical student is performing the following test on a given urine sample in the biochemistry lab. The urine sample is heated with BaSO4. The reagent, a solution of ferric chloride is added to the adsorbed precipitate. The positive test would indicate the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given biochemical test is Fouchet's test. It is used for detecting the presence of bile pigments in urine. 

In Fouchet's test, urine is heated with barium sulfate which adsorbs bilirubin. Ferric chloride is added which oxidizes the adsorbed bilirubin to biliverdin which produces a green color.

Principle for all tests to detect bile pigments: Oxidizing agents readily oxidize bilirubin to biliverdin to form a green color.

Other tests for Bile pigments:

  • Ehrlich's aldehyde reagent test - Bile pigments react with para dimethyl amino benzaldehyde to form a red color. 
  • Gmelin's test -  Nitric acid is used as the oxidizing agent. 
  • Schlesinger's test - Zinc ions are used as oxidizing agents.

questions.text: A 3-weeks-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent vomiting, and hepatosplenomegaly. Radiological imaging shows bilateral adrenal calcification. Enzyme studies revealed a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase. What is the most likely disease in this case?
questions.solution:
An infant with primary adrenal insufficiency with hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent emesis, and bilateral adrenal calcification is suggestive of Wolman's disease. It is due to the deficiency of the enzyme acid lipase.

It is a lipid disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (chromosome 10) which leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in the most visceral organs. It is an Autosomal recessive disease.

The child presents in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

questions.text: ‘X’ is an anti–epileptic drug given for treatment of partial/focal seizures and West syndrome. This is preferred in patients with a previous history of tuberous sclerosis. This drug has been given a black box warning as it can cause permanent visual loss. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The anti–epileptic drug with severe black–box warning causing the permanent visual loss is Vigabatrin and it acts by irreversibly blocking the GABA transaminase to increase GABA action. It is used in the treatment of focal seizures and infantile spasms. 

Vigabatrin causes an increase in retinal thickness and directly damages the central retina. The other side effects of the drug include:

  • Dizziness
  • Tremors
  • Weight gain
  • Memory disturbances
  • myalgia

The other anti-epileptic drugs with visual effects include the following:

2.       Phenytoin Zero order kinetics and is a Na+ channel blocker

Diplopia.

DOC for recurrent seizure prophylaxis
3.       Gabapentin Clearly not studied

Macular oedema

used in post – herpetic pain

The drug of choice for infantile spasms is ACTH.

The drug of choice for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabatrin.

Infantile spasm (IS) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities).Their occurrence is almost entirely limited to infancy (the first year of life) and they are refractory to conventional anticonvulsant drugs.

West’s syndrome refers to the classic triad of infantile spasms, characteristic interictal EEG showing hypsarrhythmia, and neurodevelopmental regression. 

ISs are resistant to most of the conventional antiepileptic drugs. Only ACTH, corticosteroids, and vigabatrin have conclusively demonstrated effectiveness.

questions.text: A woman experiences hot flushes and sweating often and has stopped to menstruate for the last one year. She suspects that she has attained menopause. It would be considered to be a premature menopause if her age is less than_____.
questions.solution:
It would be considered to be a premature menopause if her age is less than 40 years.

Menopause is the permanent cessation of ovarian function, thereby leading to permanent amenorrhea. It usually occurs between 45–50 years, but the average age of menopause is 47 years old and is confirmed after 12 months of amenorrhea.

Clinical features of menopause:

  • Hot flushes, which are transient heat sensations occurring in the face and neck and lasting for 2–5 minutes, followed by sweating
  • Insomnia, headache
  • Dyspareunia
  • Irritability, depression, tiredness
  • Lack of concentration and lack of memory 

Menopause sets in when the follicle number falls below 1000. If this occurs before 40 years of age, it is termed premature menopause, while attaining it after 55 years is delayed menopause. 

The age at which menopause is attained is not related to age at menarche, race, the number of pregnancies, socioeconomic status, or oral contraceptive pills usage. However, it is directly influenced by smoking and genetic disposition. Perimenopause is the period 3–4 years preceding menopause and is followed by 1 year of amenorrhea.

questions.text: You were asked to perform fundoscopy in a patient diagnosed with hypertensive retinopathy. You notice arteriovenous nicking with tapering of veins on either side of the crossings on fundoscopic examination. This sign is known as _______
questions.solution:
Tapering of veins on either side of the crossings is known as the Gunn sign, which is seen on fundoscopy in a patient with hypertensive retinopathy.

Arteriovenous nicking is the hallmark of hypertensive retinopathy. It occurs where the arteriole crosses and compresses the vein, as the vessels share a common adventitious sheath.

These changes are also known as A-V crossing changes and they include:

  • Salu’s sign is the deflection of veins at the arteriovenous crossings.
  • Bonnet sign is the banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings, and
  • Gunn sign is the tapering of veins on either side of the crossings.

 

Grading of Hypertensive Retinopathy:

Grade 1: Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing

Grade 2: Focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping. Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls as a copper wiring can be seen.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus dot/blot/flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton wool spots. Chronic retinal edema results in the deposition of hard exudates around the fovea as a macular star. 

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. It is a marker of malignant hypertension

questions.text: A 13-year-old child presents with acute flaccid paralysis. There's a history of mild fever, headache, and sore throat for the past 1 week. RT-PCR on a CSF sample is sent to identify the causative virus. Which of the following statements is true regarding the virus?

choices.text: Type 2 antigen is the most common cause of epidemics
Potency of injectable vaccine is measured in terms of D antigen units
Anti- C antibody is protective against the virus
C antigen is considered to be type-specific

questions.solution:
The given case scenario with a history of acute flaccid paralysis associated with fever, headache, and sore throat is suggestive of poliomyelitis. The potency of the injectable polio vaccine can be measured in terms of D antigen units.

Type 1 poliovirus is the most common cause of epidemics in populations(Statement 1).

Poliovirus strains have been classified into 3 types: 

  • Type 1- the most common and causes most of the epidemics. 
  • Type 2- endemic infections. 
  • Type 3- epidemics but rarer than type 1. 

Two antigens C and D are recognized based on complement fixation, ELISA, or precipitation tests. The D antigen also called the native or N antigen, is associated with the whole virion and is type-specific(Statement 4). The C antigen also called the heated or H antigen, is associated with the 'empty' non-infectious virus. Anti-C antibody does not neutralize virus infectivity and is not protective(Statement 3). The D antigen is converted into the C antigen by heating the virus at 56°C. Anti-D antibody is protective. 

Viral RNA is demonstrable in CSF by reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR). It can also be used for the detection of viruses from nasopharyngeal swabs (SARS-CoV2, H1N1).

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presented with complaints of breathlessness and chest pain for 1 week. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. Her chest radiograph is given below. Which of the following findings is not consistent with rheumatoid arthritis being the cause of this condition?

choices.text: High glucose in the pleural fluid
High LDH in the pleural fluid
Presence of monocytes in the pleural fluid

questions.solution:
The given chest radiograph shows a left-sided pleural effusion. High glucose is not consistent with pleural effusion due to rheumatoid arthritis, since low glucose is expected in the pleural fluid analysis of this patient.

Pleural fluid analysis in a rheumatoid pleural effusion shows:

  • Gross appearance: turbid; green-yellow color
  • pH < 7.2
  • WBC count: up to 20,000 cells/μL, can be monocytes or neutrophils
  • Rheumatoid factor: positive
  • Glucose: low (< 60 mg/dL)
  • Cholesterol crystals present

Rheumatoid pleural effusion is a type of exudative pleural effusion. Light’s criteria are used to distinguish between exudative and transudative pleural effusions. An exudative pleural effusion satisfies at least one of the following criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds of the upper limit of normal serum value

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, occasional chest pain and breathlessness, increased thirst, and increased urination for the past 6 months. The radiological investigations reveal a centrally located tumor with the histopathology showing a characteristic Azzopardi effect as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can cause ectopic release of adreno cortico trophic hormone
Salt and pepper pattern is seen on histopathological examination
Tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the histological image showing the basophilic staining of the vessel wall (Azzopardi effect) are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung. Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma. Calretinin positivity is seen in mesothelioma, not here.

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium. Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

Markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma include:

  • Chromogranin,
  • Synaptophysin,
  • CD56

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing Syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion. A majority of small-cell carcinomas (90%) show high levels of antiapoptotic BCL2 protein on Immunohistochemistry.

Small cell lung cancer-associated SIADH is due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. It resolves within a month of initiation of chemotherapy.

Immunohistochemistry in Lung cancers:

  • Primary lung adenocarcinoma (Napsin-A positive, Thyroid Transcription Factor (TTF-1) positive)
  • Primary lung squamous cell carcinoma (Napsin-A negative, TTF-1 negative)
  • Primary Small Cell Lung Cancers (Napsin-A negative, TTF-1 positive)
  • Nonsquamous NSCLC, SCLC, and mesothelioma may stain positive for CK7 and negative for CK20
  • Squamous cell lung cancer often will be both CK7 and CK20 negative
  • p63 is a useful marker for the detection of Non-Small Cell Lung Cancers with squamous differentiation when used in cytologic pulmonary samples
  • CK5/6, calretinin, and Wilms tumor gene-1 (WT-1), all of which show positivity in mesothelioma

questions.text: During the ophthalmology postings of your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by one of the senior resident. This instrument could be used to

choices.text: Test the color vision of patients
Refine the power and axis of cylindrical lens
Measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria
To visualize the angle of anterior chamber

questions.solution:
The given image shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique), which is used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens during refraction.

Other options:

Option A: Nagel’s anomaloscope given below is used to tests color vision.

Option C: Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases of torsional diplopia.

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with recurrent abdominal pain, weight loss, and diarrhea. CT Abdomen shows the following findings. All of these are characteristic features of this disease except that _____________

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and CT findings of poorly defined masses with extensive desmoplastic reaction are suggestive of pancreatic carcinoma. Vascular invasion is quite common.

Carcinomas of the body and tail of the pancreas do not impinge on the biliary tract and do not develop jaundice. They remain asymptomatic and may be quite large and widely disseminated by the time they are discovered.

Approximately 60% of cancers of the pancreas arise in the head of the gland, 15% in the body, and 5% in the tail; in 20% of the cases, the neoplasm diffusely involves the entire gland. 

Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas usually presents with jaundice. Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. This sign implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas.

Cigarette smoking is the leading preventable cause of pancreatic cancer and is believed to double the risk of pancreatic cancer.

A desmoplastic reaction is the growth of fibrous or connective tissue, which is characteristic of this cancer.

Perineural invasion as well as lymphatic and large vessel invasion are common in pancreatic carcinoma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with refractory seizures was started on an IV anti-epileptic drug. The next day, she developed blisters, erythema, and discoloration of her hand as shown below. Which of the drugs given below is likely to be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The woman would have been administered phenytoin which is responsible for Purple glove syndrome as shown in the image. 

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome (hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, hare lip, microcephaly) (First image shown below)

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

Other options: 

 

Phenobarbitone can also cause blisters (second image shown below) and bullae. But that is usually associated with chronic poisoning and is not an acute reaction. Levitracetam and Lamotrigene and very safe drugs with good efficacy. 

Better alternative for IV phenytoin:

Instead of Phenytoin, IV Fosphenytoin is preferred in the management of status epilepticus. It is a pro-drug and is rapidly converted to Phenytoin and since it is an ester, it seldom causes such reaction. 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive seizures with impaired consciousness in the interictal period.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes. The flowchart shown below summarizes the management of status epilepticus.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with dysarthria, dystonia, and depression. Ocular examination findings are shown below. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated transaminases and increased urinary copper excretion. Which of the following is not consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with dysarthria, dystonia, and depression with high urinary copper excretion and elevated liver enzymes is suggestive of Wilson's disease. The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring that occurs due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea. Low serum hepcidin is not associated with Wilson's disease, but rather with hemochromatosis.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. There is a copper overload that primarily affects the liver (leading to cirrhosis) and the brain (leading to neurologic and psychiatric symptoms). 

Clinical features of Wilson's disease include: 

  • Hepatic features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient might develop cirrhosis and acute decompensation of liver function. Massive release of copper into the circulation from the liver can lead to hemolytic anemia (option A).
  • Neurologic features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia (option D).
  • Psychiatric features include personality changes (irritability, anger) depression, and anxiety.
  • Ocular features include Kayser-Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract. 
  • Other manifestations include renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis. 

Reduced serum ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper excretion point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Percutaneous liver biopsy for measuring hepatic copper content is the gold standard investigation for establishing the diagnosis.

Copper chelation in patients with Wilson's disease is done using penicillamine. Pyridoxine is prescribed with penicillamine to counteract the deficiency that may develop with the treatment. In patients with predominant neurological manifestations, trientine is used as the chelating agent because penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms. Tetrathiomolybdate is under trial for the treatment of Wilson's disease. Zinc is used for maintenance therapy in patients after the initial chelation is complete.

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder associated with a decrease in the functioning of hepcidin. This leads to increased absorption of intestinal iron. There is a deposition of this excessive iron in parenchymal cells, leading to cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, bronze discoloration of the skin, congestive cardiac failure, hypogonadism, and arthropathy.

  • < 7 – Medical therapy
  • 7–9 – Clinical judgement, Either medical / surgical treatment
  • > 9 – Liver transplantation

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with numbness and paresthesia over the area marked with X in the image. Through which foramina does the nerve associated with this condition pass?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is supplied by the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. It passes through the foramen rotundum.

The Foramen rotundum is situated on the floor of the middle cranial fossa, posterior to the medial end of the superior orbital fissure. It serves as a passageway for the maxillary nerve (V2) as it travels from the middle cranial fossa to the pterygopalatine fossa.

The maxillary nerve is responsible for sensation over the mid-face, lower eyelid, nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, upper lip, maxillary teeth, and palate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains that he feels dejected and depressed for the past 3 years. His wife says that he has frequent mood fluctuations.  A few days a week, he appears very depressed, and on other days he is irritable and short-tempered leading to regular arguments with his wife. This causes him stress and he has recently started to consume alcohol to help himself feel better. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of depression, irritability, sudden mood fluctuations, and alcohol abuse for the past 3 years is suggestive of cyclothymic disorder.

Cyclothymia presents as a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy lasting for at least 4 consecutive days. The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.

Around half of the patients complain of depression as their major symptom but some may have primarily hypomanic symptoms. Most of these patients have problems in their social and professional lives due to this disorder. The mood changes are abrupt and occur within hours leading to a great amount of stress. This makes patients feel that they are out of control. 

Substances like alcohol, benzodiazepines, or marijuana are often used to self-medicate. In some cases during the hypomanic state patients may take cocaine, amphetamines, or hallucinogens to further stimulate themselves.

The DSM-5 criteria for diagnosis of cyclothymia:

A. For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents) there have been many periods with hypomanic symptoms not meeting the criteria for a manic episode and many periods with depressive symptoms not meeting the criteria for a major depressive episode.

B. During the above 2-year period (1 year in children and adolescents), the hypomanic and depressive periods have been present for at least half the time and the individual has not had a symptom-free interval of more than 2 months.

C. Criteria for a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode have never been met.

D. The symptoms in criterion A are not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. The symptoms cannot be explained by the physiological effects of a substance or any other medical condition.

F. The symptoms cause significant difficulties in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.

Mood stabilizers like lithium and antimanic drugs like sodium valproate are the first lines of treatment. Psychotherapy is a great way for patients to develop coping mechanisms to help with their mood swings. Patients often require life-long treatment.

Option A: Major depressive disorder usually presents with depressed mood, anhedonia, significant change in weight or appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness nearly every day. These symptoms are present for a minimum of 2 weeks. 

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. It is distinguished from major depressive disorder by the fact that patients mention that they have always been depressed. There will never be an episode of mania/hypomania in this condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who visited North America presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Radiological examination of the chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. Culture from the abscess at 37°C, shows the appearance given in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of travel to North America suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces fungi. 

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and is also called North American Blastomycosis.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in contaminated soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  • Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, military lesions or abscess formation. 
  • Disseminated disease - can lead to multiple abscesses and has high fatality.
  • Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be a papule, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis when cultured at 37°C shows thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud.

Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option B- Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis. Infection is acquired by inhalation. Most infections are asymptomatic but infection of the reticuloendothelial system manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia and it is highly fatal. 

Option C- Coccidiodes immitis is also a dimorphic fungus causing coccidiomycosis. Infection is acquired through inhalation of dust-containing spores of the fungus. Mostly they are asymptomatic and a self-limiting influenza-like fever termed valley fever or desert rheumatism develops in some individuals. The infection leads to lifetime immunity. 

Option D- Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis is again a dimorphic fungus causing paracoccidioidomycosis also termed South American blastomycosis. Infection is initially acquired by the inhalation of spores causing primary pulmonary infection. It spreads to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics by hematogenous spread resulting in ulcerative granulomas of the buccal and nasal mucosa. 

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a patient with a posterior urethral valve?

choices.text: Cathether can be passed retrogradely without difficulty

questions.solution:
The posterior urethral valve (PUV) is associated with distension of the prostatic urethra, not the bulbar urethra.

PUV is a membranous fold in the posterior urethra. They lie just distal to the verumontanum and act like flap valves. While they do obstruct the normal anterograde flow of the urine, a urethral catheter can easily be passed retrogradely.

Antenatal ultrasound shows a distended bladder, dilated prostatic urethra, and associated hydroureteronephrosis. A characteristic keyhole sign has been described in the antenatal ultrasound, as shown below. The black arrow marks the dilated prostatic urethra, while the white arrow marks the distended urinary bladder.

 

If the diagnosis is not established antenatally, parents complain of the baby having voiding trouble and recurrent urinary tract infections. Untreated PUV can lead to a decline in renal function and chronic kidney disease.

Diagnosis is established by voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), which shows dilated prostatic urethra and hypertrophied bladder with diverticulae. Initial treatment is by catheterization to drain the urine and decompress the upper part of the urinary tract. Definitive treatment is by endoscopic ablation of the valves.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old manual laborer is brought to the ER with confusion, drowsiness, and oliguria. He was working in the sun throughout the day. His examination findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

Pulse: 124 bpm

BP: 100/60 mmHg

Core temperature: 106°F

Sweating: present
questions.solution:
In the given patient with a history of exertion in the sun, along with a core temperature >105°F and the presence of sweating, a diagnosis of exertional heat stroke is most likely. 

In exertional heat stroke (EHS), the affected patients are usually previously healthy and have a history of strenuous exertion in the heat — such as military recruits, laborers, and athletes. Despite being severely dehydrated, most patients present with diaphoresis. Muscular exertion can cause rhabdomyolysis and consequent complications such as hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia. Creatine kinase is elevated and patients may have features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Renal failure can occur due to rhabdomyolysis, direct thermal injury, or volume depletion. These patients might also present with hepatic injury because of the sensitivity of hepatocytes to heat.

Classical heat stroke (option D) differs from EHS in that it usually occurs in older patients with predisposing health factors. These patients often present with anhidrosis despite high temperatures. They usually don't have abnormal electrolytes or coagulopathy unless the presentation is delayed. 

Heat syncope (option A) is when the patient collapses following exercise or prolonged standing in the heat. It is usually seen in elderly patients. It occurs due to volume depletion and peripheral vasodilation, causing postural hypotension.  

Heat exhaustion (option B) differs from heat stroke in that the thermoregulatory control measures are still functional and there is no CNS dysfunction. The core temperature is elevated but is <105°F. The diagnosis of heat exhaustion is made in a patient after excluding the presence of any symptoms that might indicate heat stroke.

questions.text: Best method to visualise the proximal bile duct is _____.
questions.solution:
Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC) is the best method to visualize the proximal bile duct.

This is an invasive technique in which a bile duct is cannulated percutaneously using the Chiba or Okuda needle. This is done under radiological control (ultrasound or CT). Successful entry is confirmed by contrast injection or aspiration of bile. Multiple images can be taken, demonstrating areas of strictures or obstruction.

In general, if a malignant stricture at the level of the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts or higher is suspected in a jaundiced patient, a PTC is preferred to ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. CSF analysis was performed and the patient was diagnosed with tubercular meningitis. The patient was also positive for HIV. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: ATT is started first followed by ART after 4 weeks
ATT and ART should be started simultaneously
ATT is started first followed by ART after 2 weeks
ART is started first followed by ATT after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
In a patient with co-existent HIV and tubercular meningitis, ART is delayed for at least 4 weeks(but initiated within 8 weeks) after starting ATT for tubercular meningitis.

Tubercular meningitis is a type of subacute meningitis. It is caused due to the hematogenous dissemination of the bacilli into the brain parenchyma. These bacilli form tubercles. The tubercles undergo caseating necrosis and release the tubercular antigens in the subarachnoid space, leading to inflammation of the meninges. They predominantly involve the basal portion of the brain.

Symptoms include headache, neck stiffness, features of cranial nerve palsies such as facial weakness, downward and outward positioning of the eyes, diminished vision, double vision, and hearing loss. Signs include papilledema, Kernig's sign, and Brudzinski's sign of meningeal irritation.

It is treated with fixed-dose combinations of isoniazid (5 mg/kg/d), rifampicin (10 mg/kg/d), pyrazinamide (30 mg/kg/d), ethambutol (15 mg/kg/d), and pyridoxine (50 mg/d) for 6 months. It can be extended by 3-6 months in cases of tubercular meningitis. Also, in HIV-negative patients with TB meningitis, dexamethasone (12–16 mg/d) is recommended for 6 weeks.

However, in a patient with coexistent tuberculosis and HIV, ART should be started as soon as possible within two weeks of initiating TB treatment, regardless of CD4 cell count. The preferred first-line ART regimen for all PLHIV with age >10 years and weight >30kg is Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir as FDC in a single pill once a day.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.

  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: All of the following structures are lined by transitional epithelium except_______
questions.solution:
Pseudostratified columnar epithelium lines the membranous urethra.

The transitional epithelium is identified by the variations in the cell layers: the deepest cell layer is columnar or cuboidal, the middle is made of polyhedral cells, and, lastly, the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped.

Transitional epithelium lines the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium. In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched, it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.  

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:
  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra - Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra - Pseudostratified columnar epithelium
  • Penile/ Spongy urethra - proximally, Pseudostratified columnar; distally, stratified squamous.

In both males and females, the greater part of the urethra is lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium. A short part adjoining the urinary bladder is lined by transitional epithelium, while the part near the external orifice is lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

The image given below shows transitional epithelium.

questions.text: An approved vaccine for a non-lethal disease A has been administered in a village containing many cases of the disease. Which of the following parameters would decrease following the administration of the vaccine?
questions.solution:
Incidence of disease would decrease following the administration of a vaccine.

Incidence refers to the number of new cases occurring in a specific population in a given period of time. It is a health indicator that is subject to variation. An increase in incidence suggests an ineffective control of the disease or a change in the etiology or environment. The introduction of vaccines helps to bring down the incidence of diseases. 

As the condition is non-fatal, the mortality rate, the survival rate, and the case fatality rate are unaffected.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A child aged 10 years presented with perianal pruritus which is worse in night. Routine stool examination didn't reveal parasite cysts or eggs. The following examination is done to recover eggs which are non-bile stained. Identify the organism causing the infection.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing scotch tape method to collect perianal egg deposition by (Enterobius vermicularis) is  suggestive of infestation with Pinworm 

Characteristics of Pinworm egg:

  • It is colorless, non-bile stained.
  • It floats in the saturated salt solution.
  • The egg is planoconvex. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.

Scotch tape method involves:

  1. Take a clear cellophane tape almost 4 cm long
  2. Hold it in such a way(or make a loop) so that sticky surface faces upwards or towards the perianal skin.
  3. Place the sticky surface of tap in the perianal area momentarily
  4. Place the sticky surface down on the glass slide. Examine under microscope.

Other eggs that can be collected by scotch tape method are Taenia solium, Taenia saginata, and Schistosoma mansoni. 

Other eggs which are non-bile stained can be remembered as NEHA - Necator americanus, Enterobius vermicularis, Hymenolepsis nana, Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of taking medications for asthma, now presents with obesity, short stature, round face, and abdominal striae. What could be the most common cause of the presenting features?
questions.solution:
The probable cause, in this case, is Exogenous glucocorticoids.

History of asthma suggests that patient had been on exogenous steroids (inhaled/systemic) for long term management of severe asthma. The presenting features with a round face (moon facies), short stature, along with obesity and purple skin striae suggest a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome and the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids. History of asthma suggests, the patient was administered long term exogenous (inhaled/systemic) steroids.

Cushing's syndrome is characterized by clinical features that result from chronic exposure of excess glucocorticoids that can be due to

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids (Iatrogenic: Most common cause of Cushing's syndrome) 
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion:
    • In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor
    • In children >7 years: Most often by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease)

Important clinical features in children

  • Obesity or weight gain (most common)
  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with a history of fatigue. Examination findings are shown below. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient presenting with fatigue and hyperpigmentation of the palms and the oral cavity (mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation), a diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most likely. The test used to confirm the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is the ACTH stimulation test (also known as the short cosyntropin test or short Synacthen test).

ACTH stimulation test involves the administration of an exogenous, synthetic peptide that has an activity similar to ACTH on the adrenal glands. Serum cortisol levels are measured prior to, and after the administration of the synthetic peptide. Cortisol levels lower than the cut-off value indicate a failure of the adrenal glands to increase the production of cortisol in response to synthetic ACTH — thus confirming the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Note that this will be seen in both primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Adrenal insufficiency can be divided into:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most commonly due to autoimmune adrenalitis. These patients are likely to develop other autoimmune diseases such as vitiligo, premature ovarian failure, and autoimmune thyroid disease. Other causes of Addison's disease include destruction of the adrenal gland due to infections such as TB, hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome due to meningococcemia) or infiltration.

Secondary adrenal insufficiency occurs due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis dysfunction. This can include iatrogenic suppression due to chronic therapy with glucocorticoids, or because of pituitary and hypothalamic tumors. Pituitary apoplexy because of hypovolemic shock during parturition (Sheehan syndrome) can also cause secondary adrenal insufficiency.

The patients present with fatigue and loss of energy. Primary adrenal insufficiency causes hyperpigmentation due to excess ACTH, which stimulates the melanocytes to produce more pigment. Hyperpigmentation is maximally seen in areas exposed to sunlight or that which undergo friction. However, secondary adrenal insufficiency presents with skin paleness due to the complete absence of ACTH. 

The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is established by the ACTH stimulation test as described above. Primary and secondary adrenal insufficiencies can be differentiated biochemically:

Primary adrenal insufficiency Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Serum cortisol after ACTH stimulation: low Serum cortisol after ACTH stimulation: low
Serum ACTH: high Serum ACTH: low
Plasma renin: high (minerocorticoid deficiency also present, since adrenal gland itself is not functioning) Plasma renin: normal (adrenal gland itself is functional and can be regulated by renin-angiotensin system)


Patients should also undergo screening for steroid autoantibodies and a CT scan of the adrenal glands to narrow down the cause of the adrenal insufficiency. 

Treatment is with oral hydrocortisone 15-25 mg/day in 2-3 divided doses. Long-acting agents are not preferred because they cause receptor activation even when the cortisol levels are supposed to be physiologically low in the body. Mineralocorticoid replacement is done with fludrocortisone 100-150 μg.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: The following type of nipple discharge is seen in?
questions.solution:
Green nipple discharge as seen in the above image can occur in duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking. The initial stages of this disease consist of the dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with debris. Accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts acts as an irritant and leads to infection and inflammation. This causes periductal mastitis and subsequent fibrosis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess. Opening of the abscess onto the skin leads to fistula formation. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation, which consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important photochemical reaction involved in phototherapy?
questions.solution:
Isomerization is the most important photochemical reaction involved in Phototherapy.

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by these mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state. 
  • Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation.    

The most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia ranges from 460–490 nm (Blue-green light).

questions.text: A newborn male baby was diagnosed with undescended testis on the left side. The testis has not descended even after 3 months and an orchiopexy is planned. What is the most appropriate time for this surgery?

choices.text: When the age of the infant is less than 6 months
When the age of the infant is between 6 and 18 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate time for orchidopexy is between 6 to 18 months of age.

Orchidopexy is the surgery of choice for undescended testes. It is done in order to prevent the complications that might occur if the testes continue to remain inside the abdomen, such as infertility and the risk of malignancy. The surgery is usually performed between the ages of 6 months to 18 months. The testes and the spermatic cord are mobilized, the fibrous adhesions around the deep ring are divided, and the testes are repositioned in the scrotum, in a pouch constructed between the dartos muscle and the skin.

Cryptorchidism refers to the incomplete descent of the testes, but in their normal path from the abdomen to the scrotum. If they lie outside the normal path, they are referred to as ectopic testes. The occurrence of cryptorchidism is more common in premature infants. In two-thirds of the cases, the testes will reach the scrotum by 3 months of life; full descent after this time is unlikely. The descent of the testes may be arrested in any of the following positions:

  • Abdominal (15%)
  • Inguinal (25%)
  • High up in the scrotum (60%)
Undescended testes can give rise to a number of more serious consequences. This includes infertility, testicular malignancy, and testicular torsion. By the second year of life, there is a significant degeneration of the spermatogenic tissue. An orchidopexy done during adulthood (after puberty) will result in no significant fertility benefits and no reduction in the risk of testicular malignancy. Therefore, orchidopexy should be done as early as possible within the recommended age to prevent the occurrence of these complications. 
 
One important differential to be considered in these patients is retractile testis. Because of the strong cremasteric reflex, the stimulation of the scrotal skin causes the testis to ascend upwards and disappear into the inguinal canal. If it is a case of retractile testis, the scrotal skin will be well developed, in contrast to the underdeveloped scrotal skin seen in cryptorchidism. Further, the retractile testis that has ascended into the inguinal canal can be gently milked downwards, but this is not the case with true undescended testis.
 
In most cases of cryptorchidism, the testis can be palpated in the inguinal region and thus local exploration and orchidopexy can be done. In cases when the testis is not palpable, ultrasound and laparoscopy are done to pinpoint the location of the testis and plan further management. questions.text: Maintenance dose of a drug primarily depends upon _________
questions.solution:
The maintenance dose of a drug primarily depends upon clearance (or plasma half-life) of the drug. It is the dose that has to be repeated at specified intervals after the attainment of the target plasma concentration, in order to maintain it.

Other options:

Option A: The loading dose of the drug is primarily dependent on the volume of distribution. 

Options C and D: Volume of distribution (Vd) refers to the volume that would accommodate the entire drug in the body if the concentration was the same as in plasma. Vd is governed by the lipid solubility and charge of the drug, the degree of the plasma protein binding, and the affinity of the drug for the different tissues of the body.  A low Vd is seen with drugs that have extensive plasma protein binding and vice versa.

questions.text:
Match the following CNS tumors with their histological findings.
CNS tumors Histological feature
1. Pilocytic astrocytoma a. Homer Wright rosettes
2. Oligodendroglioma b. Verocay bodies
3. Medulloblastoma c. Rosenthal fibers
4. Schwannoma d. Fried-egg appearance of tumor cells.
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

CNS tumors Histological feature
1. Pilocytic astrocytoma

c. Rosenthal fibers
2. Oligodendroglioma

d. Fried-egg appearance of tumor cells.
3. Medulloblastoma

a. Homer Wright rosettes
4. Schwannoma

b. Verocay bodies

 

Microscopically, Schwannoma is comprised of a mixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively. 

  • Antoni A areas are dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern
  • The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.
  • Antoni A area leaves central nuclear-free zones surrounded by the palisading of nuclei, resulting in the formation of structures termed Verocay bodies.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: An obese patient presents to the OPD with severe abdominal pain. The patient was referred for a USG scan. Which of the following is the best USG probe that can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
A curvilinear probe is the best USG probe for an obese patient with abdominal pain.

In USG

Frequency ∝ Resolution
                      Depth of penetration
                        
The curvilinear probe is a low-frequency probe. Hence there will be a higher depth of penetration and lower resolution. Hence it is used for evaluation of the abdomen and pelvis.

Other options

Option B: The linear probe is a high-frequency probe. Hence there will be a lower depth of penetration and higher resolution. It is used for the evaluation of superficial structures like breasts, thyroid, etc.

Option C: Endocavitary probe includes transrectal and transvaginal probe.

Option D: Hockey-stick transducer has a high-frequency probe. This transducer is used for evaluating small superficial structures as it has better image resolution. It is not used for deeper structures because of its small field of view and limited depth penetration.
