questions.solution:
Gene signature panels such as Oncotype Dx test help in assessing the benefit of chemotherapy in low-risk breast tumors (ER positive, HER2/neu negative, lymph node negative).

Oncotype Dx assay is a molecular test based on the assessment of 21 genes. It is the most widely used test to give a risk of recurrence (ROR) score. If the ROR is low, chemotherapy can be avoided in patients with otherwise low-risk breast tumors.

Related Pearl: Newer molecular tests in breast cancer

Newer molecular tests for breast cancer have been developed, which help in predicting the advantage of adding chemotherapy. These are:

  • Oncotype Dx (21-geneassay)
  • Mammaprint (70-gene assay)
  • EndoPredict (12-gene assay)
  • PAM50 (50-gene assay)

Oncotype Dx can only be used in hormone (ER, PR) receptor-positive cancers, while mammaprint can be used in both hormone receptor (ER, PR) positive and hormone receptor-negative cancers. 

These tests are used for T1,2 N0 M0 breast cancers – (node-negative, metastasis-negative). Using these molecular tests, a recurrence score (0 – 100) is calculated.

  • If the score is low, then there is no advantage of adding chemotherapy
  • If the score is high, then chemotherapy should be added

questions.text:
Match the given drugs to their corresponding mechanism of action.
Drug Mechanism of action

1. Etidronate

 A. High-affinity binding to RANKL

2. Cinacalcet

 B. Induces osteoclast apoptosis 

3. Denosumab

 C. Increased osteoblastic activity

4. Teriparatide

 D. Enhance sensitivity of CaSR to circulating Ca2+

 

CaSR: Calcium-sensing receptor.
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C. 

Etidronate belongs to the bisphosphonates class of drugs. It is a pyrophosphate analog that acts by directly inhibiting bone absorption. This is achieved by inducing osteoclast apoptosis as well as the prevention of hydroxyapatite dissolution. They also directly inhibit osteoclasts. It is used to treat Paget disease, tumor-associated osteolysis, and osteoporosis.

Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic that acts by increasing the sensitivity of the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) to circulating Ca2+. It thereby inhibits the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands. It is used as a pharmacotherapeutic alternative to surgery in PTH hypersecretion disorders such as parathyroid carcinoma and secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney. 

Denosumab is a human monoclonal antibody with a mechanism of action similar to that of osteoprotegerin (OPG). It binds to RANK Ligand (RANKL), thereby inhibiting its binding to the RANK receptor of the surface of osteoclasts. This prevents RANK receptor activation and subsequent bone resorption. It is used in the treatment of osteoporosis.

Teriparatide is a recombinant PTH analog that has an anabolic effect on bone homeostasis. It increases osteoblastic activity by increasing the expression of pro-osteoblastogenic growth factors (IGF1, FGF2) and transcriptional factors (Runx2). They promote osteoblast survival and differentiation. It is used in the treatment of postmenopausal and glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis. 

Note: Some other drugs used in the management of osteoporosis

  • Calcitonin - It is an indigenous hormone secreted by the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland. It prevents bone resorption by osteoclasts. WIth time it reduces both bone formation and resorption. The ultimate result is a modest increase in bone mass, especially in patients with increased rates of bone turnover.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) - Estrogen has a protective effect that prevents accelerated bone loss. This is carried out by reducing the bone resorption effects of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Keeping in line with these effects, osteoporosis prevention in postmenopausal women has been attributed to the use of SERMs such as raloxifene. It acts as a selective estrogen agonist on bone (with antiestrogen effects on breast- protective against CA breast).

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is arrested under Sec. 290 IPC for rubbing his genitals against a female passenger in the local bus. Which one of the following terms describes this particular sexual offense?
questions.solution:
Frotteurism is the term used to describe the non-consensual act of rubbing one's genitals against another person for the purpose of sexual arousal and gratification.

Offenders are usually males and these offenses are prone to occur in crowded trains and buses. This sexual offense is liable to punishment under  Section 290 IPC (fine of Rs. 200/-) as well as Sec. 291 IPC (imprisonment for 6 months and/ or fine) for creating a nuisance to the public. 

Other options:

Option A: Voyeurism is a sexual offense wherein the alleged offender observes/ spies on unsuspecting people while they undress, take baths or engage in intercourse with their partners. Their purpose is to obtain sexual gratification. It is a punishable sexual offense under Sec. 354-C IPC by imprisonment (1-3 years) and fine. For the second and subsequent offense, the punishment by imprisonment for 3-7 years.

Option C: Exhibitionism is a sexual offense characterized by intentional genital exposure in public spaces, usually directed towards unsuspecting children and females, to obtain sexual gratification. This offense is liable to punishment under Sec. 294 IPC (imprisonment up to 3 months with/without a fine). 

Option D: Masochism is a type of paraphilia wherein the person achieves sexual gratification when they receive painful stimuli from their sexual partner.

questions.text: Saccule in larynx is an extension of_____
questions.solution:
The saccule of the larynx is an extension of the ventricle.

The deep elliptical space present between vestibular and vocal folds is known as the ventricle or sinus of the larynx. The saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane that arises from the anterior part of this ventricular cavity. It extends upwards between vestibular folds and the lamina of the thyroid. When the saccule is abnormally enlarged and distended, it may form an air-containing sac in the neck known as a laryngocele.

Other options:

Options A and B: Two potential spaces within the larynx provide an avenue for the spread of tumors and are continuous with each other.

The pre-epiglottic space of Boyer is bounded:

  • Superiorly by the hyoepiglottic ligament
  • Anteriorly by the thyroid and thyrohyoid membrane
  • Posteromedially by the infrahyoid epiglottis and quadrangular membrane.

The paraglottic space is bounded:

  • Laterally by thyroid
  • Medially by ventricle and quadrangular membrane
  • Inferomedially by conus elasticus
  • Posteriorly by pyriform sinus.

Option C: Reinke's space lies under the epithelium of vocal cords. It has the following boundaries :

  • Superior and inferiorly by arcuate lines
  • Anteriorly by anterior commissure
  • Posteriorly by vocal process of arytenoid

questions.text: Deficiency of complement components C5-C8 leads to ______

choices.text: Recurrent infections with gram negative cocci
Recurrent swelling of the lips and tongue

questions.solution:
Deficiency of terminal complement components (C5-C8) leads to recurrent infections with gram negative cocci. 

  • C1 inhibitor deficiency - Hereditary angioedema. 
  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - SLE and other Collagen vascular disorders.
  • C5-C8 deficiency - Recurrent bacteremia with Neisseria. 
  • CD 59 deficiency - Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

Related Pearl: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

 

Complement protein Effects of deficiency

C5-C9 Susceptibility to Neisseria

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: You are asked to calculate the qSOFA score for a patient in the ICU. Which of the following will be given one point in the score?
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, a GCS of 14 will be given one point in the qSOFA scoring system.

Quick sequential organ failure assessment (qSOFA) is a bedside clinical tool for identifying patients with suspected sepsis who are likely to have a prolonged ICU stay or to die in the hospital. It is a convenient test since it is not based on any laboratory findings and relies solely on clinical criteria. It includes the following three clinical parameters, with one point given for each parameter.

  • Low blood pressure (SBP ≤ 100 mmHg)
  • High respiratory rate (RR ≥ 22 breaths per min)
  • Altered mental status (GCS <15)

If qSOFA score ≥ 2, the patient is considered qSOFA positive and is at high risk for prolonged ICU stay. It should prompt further investigations to assess for evidence of organ dysfunction.

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. An acute change in total SOFA score by ≥ 2 points from the baseline indicates the beginning of organ dysfunction. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Mean arterial pressure
  • PaO2/FiO2 ratio
  • GCS score
  • Administration of vasopressors
  • Serum creatinine or urine output
  • Serum bilirubin
  • Platelet count

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who suffered myocardial infarction was given aspirin and another drug that acts by inhibiting thrombin-induced activation of platelets. The other drug given along with aspirin is _________
questions.solution:
The other drug given along with aspirin in patients with myocardial infarction is Vorapaxar. Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of PAR-1(Protease Activated Receptor-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.  

Abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide act by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

Eptifibatide is contraindicated in renal failure and tirofiban needs dose adjustment in cases of renal impairment.

questions.text: A  farmer was presented with a suppurative wound on his arm and respiratory symptoms. Later he was diagnosed with melioidosis. The causative organism of this disease belongs to which category of bioterrorism agents as classified by CDC?
questions.solution:
Melioidosis is caused by burkholderia pseudomallei and it belongs to category B agent of bioterrorism as classified by CDC.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. The incubation period can be as short as 2–3 days,  months, or years. A suppurative wound infection can occur at the inoculation site which may lead to sepsis and multi-organ involvement. It is presented as fever with leukocytosis. Chest x-ray shows upper lobe consolidation. Gram staining with Wright's or methylene blue shows a gram-negative organism.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back to glucose inside the liver and kidney cells. This conversion cycle is called as _________
questions.solution:
The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles and RBCs, back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle. It links gluconeogenesis and anaerobic glycolysis.

Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and RBCs. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. This entire process is called Cori’s cycle or the glucose–lactate cycle.

Significance: The cycle's importance is based on the prevention of lactic acidosis in the muscle under anaerobic conditions. However, normally before this happens the lactic acid is moved out of the muscles and into the liver.

Other options

Option A- Cahill cycle is also called the glucose–alanine cycle. In the fasting state, there is a significant output of alanine from skeletal muscle obtained from glycolysis of muscle glycogen. Alanine is derived from the transamination of pyruvate obtained from glycolysis. Alanine is then exported to the liver where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis.

Option C- Kreb's cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins because glucose, fatty acids, and most amino acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA or intermediates of the cycle.

Option D- Urea cycle is also known as the Krebs–Henseleit cycle. It forms urea by detoxifying ammonia in the liver.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was taking treatment for leprosy for the past 6 weeks. She now comes with exfoliative dermatitis associated with fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dapsone syndrome, which is occasionally seen in leprosy patients taking dapsone.

DDS syndrome (Dapsone Syndrome) is a rarely seen side effect of dapsone therapy in leprosy patients. It starts after 6 weeks of starting dapsone and leads to exfoliative dermatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever, and hepatitis and may be fatal.

Dapsone is a structural analogue of PABA and a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway.

The uses of dapsone are:

  • Infections
    • Leprosy
    • Pneumocystis jiroveci infections
    • Malaria
    • Toxoplasma gondi infections (prophylaxis)
  • Inflammatory conditions
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis
    • Pemphigoid
    • Relapsing chondritis
    • Linear IgA bullous disease

questions.text: The nucleus of which of the following cranial nerves is located deep to the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle, and the facial colliculus is marked. The nucleus of abducens nerve lies underneath the facial colliculus. 

The facial colliculus is present in the superior part, which presents as a small elevation produced by the root of the facial nerve winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve. Columns are formed by groups of facial neurons, which innervate individual muscles and give branches of the facial nerve. Dorsal neurons innervate muscles in the scalp and upper face and ventral neurons supply the lower facial musculature. 

The fourth ventricle is located between the brainstem and the cerebellum. The rhomboid fossa is a diamond-shaped depression seen on the floor of the fourth ventricle. The superior and the inferior parts of the floor are triangular in shape. It is divided by a longitudinal median sulcus into two halves. Each half is again divided into the medial and lateral regions.

 

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: An elderly man presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food for the past 7 months. He also complains of a feeling of food getting stuck in his throat. Serial images of barium swallow are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It occurs between the oblique and horizontal fibres of inferior constrictor

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the barium swallow images are suggestive of Zenker’s diverticulum, which is a false diverticulum.

A true diverticulum involves all the layers (mucosa, submucosa, muscularis). Since Zenker's diverticulum involves only the mucosa coming out through Killian's dehiscence, it is considered a false type of diverticulum. Furthermore, it is a pulsion type of diverticulum — that is, it develops due to the high pressure present inside the pharynx and not due to any pulling force from the outside.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: After a road traffic accident, an old man experienced the sudden blurring of vision and floaters in his right eye. What would be the ideal investigation of choice for the suspected vitreous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is an ultrasound B-scan.

B-scan ultrasonography in unclotted vitreous hemorrhage generally shows a uniform appearance, and once cellular aggregates develop, small particulate echoes become visible.

USG B can also be used to assess posterior segment in the case of opaque media, and study intraocular tumors, orbital tumors, and other mass lesions. 

Vitreous hemorrhage has a variable presentation depending on the severity of the hemorrhage. The mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision.

Causes

  • Acute posterior vitreous detachment associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vessel
  • Proliferative retinopathy
    • Diabetic
    • Retinal vein occlusion
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Eales disease
    • Vasculitis
  • Miscellaneous retinal disorders
    • Macroaneurysm
    • Telangiectasia
    • Capillary hemangioma
  • Trauma
  • Systemic
    • Bleeding disorders
    • Terson syndrome

Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.

Terson syndrome
Terson syndrome refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.

Other options: 

Option A - Optical coherence tomography is used to provide cross-sectional or tomographic images of tissues of less than 10um axial resolution using light waves. It is used to image the anterior chamber angle, trabeculotomy blebs, tumors and cysts of the iris and ciliary body, macular disorders, diagnose glaucoma and in pachymetry. 

Option B - Ultrasound A-scan produces a unidimensional image. It is used to measure axial length, anterior chamber depth, and thickness of intraocular masses. 

Option D - Electroretinography records changes in the resting potential of the eye that are induced by flashes of light. It is used to evaluate retinal disorders, function, especially in cases where fundal examination is not possible.

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their Hounsfield unit values.
1. Air A. 0 HU
2. Fat B. 60-90 HU
3. Water C. -100 HU
4. Acute Blood Clot D. -1000 HU
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B.

1. Air D. -1000 HU
2. Fat C. -100 HU
3. Water A. 0 HU
4. Acute Blood Clot B. 60-90 HU

On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(μ) at that point in the body. CT number is a scaled version of μ that is normalized to the X-ray attenuation of water (μW).

CT = 1000 × (μ/μW − 1)

The resulting numbers are called ‘Hounsfield units’(HU). Due to this normalization, water is assigned 0 HU, and air is assigned a CT number of −1000 HU.

CT numbers:

  • Water = 0 HU
  • Solid soft tissues are centered around 0 HU
  • Lungs = -1000 HU
  • Air = −1000 HU
  • Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU
  • Acute Blood Clot = 60-90 HU
  • Fat = -100 HU

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-year-old child to the pediatrician after the baby developed a high fever and rashes over the body. She says that the baby initially had a very high fever, running nose, and redness of eyes. After 3 days, the fever came down, but the baby started to develop rashes. It initially started on the trunk and then spread to the face, neck, and other parts of the body. On examination, you notice multiple erythematous and maculopapular rashes over the body of the baby. Oral examination reveals lesions at the uvulopalatoglossal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is roseola infantum. The pattern of fever, the timing and pattern of spread of the rashes, and the presence of lesions at the uvulopalatoglossal junction favor the diagnosis.

Roseola infantum (also called sixth disease and exanthem subitum) is an infection caused by the human herpesvirus 6 (HHV- 6)and human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The majority of the cases are caused by HHV-6. 

It is characterized by the abrupt onset of high fever, which may be accompanied by a runny nose, redness of eyes, etc. The fever usually comes down after 3 days followed by the appearance of faint pink or rose-colored nonpruritic morbilliform rash. The rashes first appear in the trunk and then spread to the rest of the body. In a few people, there might also be ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction, which are called Nagayama spots.

Hydration and antipyretics are recommended for the management.

Other options 

Option A: Measles is characterized by prodromal symptoms like fever, running nose conjunctival congestion, etc. On the second day, gray white-colored sand-like lesions appear over the mucosa opposite to the lower second molars. These are called Koplik spots. The rash appears on the 4th day. It first appears behind the ears, along the hairline, and then spreads to the face, neck, and other parts of the body.

Option C: Chickenpox also presents with fever and rash. The rash appears within 24 to 48 hours after the appearance of the fever. It first starts on the trunk and then spreads to the face and other parts of the body. It evolves into clear fluid-filled vesicles, clouded vesicles, and then crusted vesicles. Several skin lesions with different sizes and different stages of evolution can be seen simultaneously.

Option D: Rubella presents with fever, rash, and lymphadenopathy. The pink maculopapular rash first appears on the face and then spreads to trunk and extremities within 24 hours. Enanthem on the soft palate can be observed which are called Forchheimer spots.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: What is the name of the program whose logo is depicted below?

choices.text: Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment
Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan.

questions.text: A primigravida comes to you for her first antenatal visit. You discover on routine investigations that her blood group is B negative while her husbands' is B positive. You reassure her and explain to her the role of anti D injections in the prevention of red cell alloimmunization pevention. Which of the following is true about anti D immunoprophylaxis:

choices.text: Can be administered IM or IV depending on the preparation
The half life of anti D is 60 days
It is given 72 hrs postpartum irrespective of the baby's blood group
300 mcg of anti D can neutralize 20 ml of fetal red blood cells

questions.solution:
Anti-D immune globulin can be administered via IM/IV route depending on the preparation.

Anti-D immune globulin is derived from the plasma of individuals who have a high titer of these antibodies. Formulations that are prepared by cold ethanol fractionation and ultrafiltration contain plasma proteins that could result in anaphylaxis if given intravenously. Thus, they must be administered intramuscularly. However, formulations prepared by ion exchange chromatography may be administered either intramuscularly or intravenously.

Other options:

Option B: The half-life of anti-D is 16-24 days due to which it is usually administered in the third trimester and following delivery.

Option C: Anti-D is given to an unsensitized mother at 28 weeks and then again postpartum. The postpartum dose has to be given within 72 hrs of delivery and only if the baby is Rh-positive.

Option D: 300 micrograms of Anti D can neutralize 15 ml of fetal RBCs or 30 ml of fetal whole blood. If the volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage is greater than 30 mL whole blood, the dose of Rh-immune globulin is calculated as 10 μg for every 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of staphyloma at point D in the given image?
questions.solution:
Degenerative high axial myopia is the most common cause for posterior staphyloma (Point D)

Staphyloma:

  • It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.
  • So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.
  • In the image:
    • A: Intercalary staphyloma
    • B: Ciliary staphyloma
    • C: Equatorial staphyloma
    • D: Posterior staphyloma

questions.text: You perform Pinard's manoeuvre while conducting a delivery. Which of these other manoeuvres are you least likely to have performed to deliver this baby?
questions.solution:
Pinard's maneuver is used in case of a breech presentation while Wood's maneuver is used in shoulder presentation, thus making Wood's less likely to be performed in this delivery.

Pinard’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

Lovset’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

 

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre is shown in the image. It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Wood's corkscrew manoeuvre :

Rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion in case of shoulder dystocia.

  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: There is an outbreak of measles in the community. R0(R naught) was calculated which was >1. What does this indicate?

choices.text: Total number of deaths is expected to increase
Total number of deaths is expected to decrease
The outbreak is expected to decline
The outbreak is expected to continue

questions.solution:
The R0 value of >1 indicates that the outbreak is expected to continue.

The basic reproduction number (R0) is an indicator of the contagiousness or transmissibility of infectious and parasitic agents. It is the average expected number of new cases infected by a primary case. R0 can be affected by various factors such as the probability of transmission upon contact between an infected case and a susceptible person, the frequency of contact, and the duration of infection in a person.

R0 >1: Outbreak is expected to continue (Increase in number of cases
R0 <1: Outbreak is expected to end (Decline in number of cases)

R0 can be used to estimate the proportion of the population that must be vaccinated to eliminate infection from that population.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female who is on symptomatic therapy for osteoarthritis for 15 years came to the hospital with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspepsia. Endoscopy showed gastric mucosal inflammation and ulcer. Which of the following drugs is approved by the FDA for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is likely to be on NSAIDs as a symptomatic therapy for osteoarthritis. NSAIDs cause gastric ulcers by inhibiting protective action on mucosa by prostaglandins. PGE1 analogue (Misoprostol) is approved by the FDA for NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.

Prostaglandins inhibit and reduce gastric acid secretion in a dose-dependent manner. They also increase mucosal blood flow and stimulate bicarbonate and mucin secretion which contribute to its cytoprotective action.

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient with increased blood pressure has come to the outpatient department. He asks about lifestyle modifications and a DASH diet was suggested. How much does the systolic blood pressure drop by adopting the DASH diet?

DASH: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension
questions.solution:
The systolic blood pressure drops by 8-14 mmHg by adopting the DASH diet.

DASH is a diet plan which involves consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced fat content. 

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension and the reduction in blood pressure are shown below.

Modification Impact on SBP
Weight reduction to maintain a normal body mass index 5–20 mmHg per 10kg weight loss
DASH diet 8–14 mmHg
Sodium intake reduction (< 6 grams of sodium chloride) 2–8 mmHg
Physical activity: 30 minutes of a brisk walk per day  4–9 mmHg

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Hypertension is a preventable disease. There are two approaches:

  • Primary prevention - includes measures that are taken to reduce the incidence by reducing the risk of onset. Population strategies are dietary modification, weight reduction, and exercise. A high-risk strategy prevents the shooting of blood pressure which might need institutional treatment.
  • Secondary prevention - includes the detection and usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals.

questions.text: A group of scientists are studying gastric cancer.  They extract DNA from the cell and cleave it using a restriction enzyme. They separate the DNA fragments by running them on an electrophoresis gel. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose paper and the gene of interest is isolated by exposing it to labeled DNA probe. Which of the following laboratory techniques does this describe?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes the Southern blot. This technique is used to detect mutations in DNA.

Procedure:

DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe (DNA, RNA, or oligonucleotides).

Variants of Southern blot are:

  • Northern blot- It is similar to Southern blot except that the sample is a mixture of mRNA molecules that are separated by electrophoresis. It is then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with a radiolabeled probe.
  • Western blot (also called immunoblots)- It is also similar to southern blots, except that the proteins are taken as samples and the probe is labeled antibody.

A polymerase chain reaction is a technique to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It uses DNA polymerases to amplify the targeted portions of the DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the citrullination of histones, during the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps?
questions.solution:
Arginine deaminase is responsible for the citrullination of histones, during the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps.

The initiation of neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation involves the activation of an arginine deaminase through reactive oxygen species (ROS), which converts arginine into citrulline, resulting in the decondensation of chromatin structure. Subsequently, additional enzymes produced in activated neutrophils, like myeloperoxidase (MPO) and elastase, penetrate the nucleus and induce further chromatin relaxation. This process eventually leads to the disruption of the nuclear membrane and the release of chromatin.

NETs are networks of extracellular fibers that consist of a viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin. They trap microbes at sites of infection, preventing their further spread. They also contain a high concentration of antimicrobial proteins like neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G, and histones that have a high affinity for DNA.

They are produced by neutrophils in response to the following triggers:

  • Pathogens - Mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators -
    • Chemokines
    • Cytokines (mainly interferons)
    • Complement proteins
    • Reactive oxygen species

NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis. In this condition, platelet activation is involved in the NET formation. The nuclear chromatin in the NETs is a source of nuclear antigens (histones and associated DNA) in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This triggers autoantibody production and further clinical manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Superoxide dismutases (SODs) are present in various cell types and play a role in converting oxygen (O2) into hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). This group of enzymes consists of manganese-SOD, which is predominantly found in mitochondria, and copper-zinc-SOD, which is primarily located in the cytoplasm. Their function is to assist in the elimination of free radicals.

Option B: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are generated through the swift assembly and activation of a complex oxidase known as NADPH oxidase, or phagocyte oxidase. This oxidase facilitates the conversion of oxygen into superoxide anions.

Option C: Nuclear alterations in necrosis occur due to the degradation of DNA. One pattern involves the fading of chromatin basophilia, known as karyolysis, which likely occurs due to the enzymatic breakdown of DNA by endonucleases.

questions.text: A 13-year-old child who weighs 70 kg weight and is a known case of hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 13 year old obese child with hypothyroidism with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip and tenderness in Scarpa's triangle points towards a diagnosis of slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE).

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

  • Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign. Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck.

 

Other options-

Option A: Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

Option C: Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option D: Fracture neck of the femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include comorbidities (diabetes, chronic kidney, and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors).

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presented with hematuria, pedal edema, and hypertension. He also gives a history of episodes of hemoptysis in the past. His renal biopsy showed crescent formation and a linear pattern of staining on immunofluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the renal biopsy findings are suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome also known as anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

In Goodpasture syndrome, antibodies that are directed against the GBM also cross-react with the basement membrane of the alveoli of the lung. This causes the characteristic clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure. The antibodies are targetted against a peptide in the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. In the kidney, anti-GBM antibodies lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which is characterized by the formation of crescents. On immunofluorescence, deposition of IgG and C3 is seen in a linear pattern along the GBM.

Other options:

Option A: Mutation of type IV (α5 chain) collagen is responsible for Alport syndrome, which presents with haematuria, ophthalmologic conditions (such as anterior lenticonus), and sensorineural hearing loss. This condition most commonly occurs as an X-linked dominant condition, and males express the full syndrome. Female heterozygotes typically present with just hematuria. Electron microscopy findings include a glomerular basement membrane with alternating portions of thickening and thinning associated with splitting the of lamina densa, known as a basket-weave appearance.

Option C: The typical sign of IgA nephropathy is episodic hematuria linked to the deposition of IgA in the mesangium. Recurrent episodes of macroscopic hematuria during or right after an upper respiratory infection, frequently accompanied by proteinuria, and persistent asymptomatic microscopic hematuria is the two most typical manifestations of IgA nephropathy. Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits are seen on electron microscopy.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) involves the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. A c-ANCA pattern with positive anti-PR3 antibodies is seen. A lung biopsy will show evidence of vasculitis and necrotizing granuloma formation, which is characteristic of this disease. Renal abnormalities vary from mild instances characterized by focal glomerular necrosis and isolated thrombosis of the capillary loops (known as focal and segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis), to more severe glomerular lesions featuring widespread necrosis accompanied by the proliferation of parietal cells, leading to the formation of crescents (referred to as crescentic glomerulonephritis).

questions.text: An autopsy is being performed on the corpse of a 50-year-old HIV-infected patient. The forensic medicine resident uses a technique of in situ dissection combined with en block removal of organs. This technique is known as_____
questions.solution:
Rokitansky's technique involves performing in situ dissection combined with en block removal of organs.

It is considered the ideal method for patients affected with highly contagious illnesses like HIV and hepatitis B.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, you note flexion, abduction, external rotation, and lengthening of the lower limb. Which of the following radiographic findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient presenting with flexion, abduction, external rotation, and lengthening of the lower limb is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip which is represented in radiograph 3 of the given image.

Anterior dislocation of the hip is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident.

On physical examination, the affected limb will be abducted and externally rotated. It is also slightly flexed. Additionally, a prominent anterior bulge will be present either in the pubic region or in the groin region.

According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as:

  • Type I - Superior or pubic
  • Type II - Inferior or obturator

Radiological findings include:

  • The displaced femoral head will appear larger than the normal side
  • As the thigh is externally rotated lesser trochanter is more prominent
  • A lateral view X-ray will be confirmatory. 

Treatment of anterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. If closed reduction fails, an open procedure may be planned. 

The given image shows a patient with an externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed left leg due to anterior dislocation of the hip:

 

Other options:

Radiograph 1-  Intertrochanteric fracture of the femur- This is usually sustained following a fall or RTA and the leg is short and externally rotated. Clinical findings are more marked than the neck of femur fractures.

Radiograph 2- Posterior dislocation of the hip- This is commonly seen following dashboard injuries and in this condition, the patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized
  • The femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen 

Radiograph 4- Fracture neck of the femur - This can present with shortening and external rotation of the limb.

Radiological findings include:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • Break in the medial cortex
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in the Shenton's line

questions.text: After a disaster, improvement in the standard quality of schools and other public buildings is being done, in order to prevent medical casualties. At which stage of the disaster management cycle is this carried out?
questions.solution:
The given plan to build standard quality buildings to prevent medical casualties is done during Mitigation, in the cycle of management sequence of a sudden onset disaster.

The correct sequence of steps is disaster impact – response – rehabilitation – reconstruction – mitigation – preparedness.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with the following finding. The patient reports severe, continuous pain and the surgeon is unable to reduce the protrusion. Which of the following is the surgery of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image shows rectal prolapse. A history of irreducible rectal prolapse with severe and continuous pain is suggestive of incarcerated rectal prolapse, most likely getting strangulated. In such a case, the surgery of choice is Altemeier's procedure.

Altemeier's procedure is a perineal approach surgery for rectal prolapse. It involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal, followed by full-thickness resection of the rectum. Following this, colorectal continuity is established by stapled or hand-sewn anastomosis. Since the procedure involves full-thickness resection of the rectum, it is the surgery of choice for patients who are presenting with incarcerated (irreducible) or strangulated (compromised vascularity) rectal prolapse.

When the layers of the rectum protrude through the anal orifice, it is termed rectal prolapse. Depending on the layers which protrude out, it can be divided as:

  • In partial rectal prolapse, only the mucosal layer of the rectum is prolapsed. It is often seen in children. The first episode is managed by digital repositioning. If there is a recurrence, then injection sclerotherapy is done. 
  • Complete rectal prolapse or full-thickness prolapse involves all the layers of the rectum. It is most often seen in adults due to the weakening of the pelvic floor and chronic straining. The surgical approaches to manage complete rectal prolapse are given below.

Perineal approaches have the advantage of minimal post-op pain, early mobility of the patient, and lower morbidity due to the surgery. However, they are associated with higher recurrence compared to the abdominal approaches. Perineal approaches include:

  • Thiersch's procedure involves the placement of a steel wire/nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. This is rarely done now because it is associated with chronic perineal infection and stenosis of the anal canal.
  • Delorme's procedure involves circumferential stripping of the mucosa from the rectum throughout the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is then plicated with a series of sutures. The excess rectal mucosa is excised and a mucosal anastomosis is performed.
  • Altemeier's procedure has already been described above.

Abdominal operations can be laparoscopic or open. They are associated with a higher risk of damage to the pelvic autonomic nerves, causing sexual dysfunction. Thus, perineal approaches are preferred in young patients.

  • Anterior mesh rectopexy / Ripstein's procedure involves the suturing of a prosthetic mesh to the anterior part of the rectum and sacral promontory. 
  • Posterior mesh rectopexy / Well's procedure involves suturing of a prosthetic mesh to the posterior part of the lower rectum and the sacral promontory.
  • Laparoscopic ventral mesh rectopexy / D'Hoore's procedure involves suturing of a prosthetic mesh to the distal-most part of the anterior wall of the rectum and sacral promontory. In addition, the posterior part of the vagina is sutured to the mesh, thus reinforcing the rectovaginal septum.

questions.text:
A patient came to the emergency department with dyspnea. He was confused, anxious and hallucinating. Inital management was started and ABG analysis was sent. ABG shows the following. What is acid-base disorder shown?

pH: 7.25

pCO2: 70 mmHg

HCO3‾: 26 mEq/L

pO2: 45 mmHg
questions.solution:
The given ABG indicates respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is decreased. This signifies acidosis. 

Step 2: In this case, pCO2 has increased by 30 mmHg. This signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 3: Plasma HCO3- has increased by 26 - 24 = 2 mEq/L. This signifies compensation is taking place.

In acute conditions, for every 10 mmHg rise in pCO2 expected rise in plasma HCO3- is 1mEq/L. In this case, pCO2 has risen by 30 mmHg, so the expected rise in HCO3- is 3 mEq/L. However, plasma HCO3- has risen only by 2 mEq/L, which implies that currently, the compensation is only partial.

The given scenario is suggestive of acute hypercapnia. The patients with acute hypercapnia present with anxiety, dyspnea, confusion, psychosis, and hallucinations, and may progress to coma. The management includes treating the underlying condition, and trying to bring back the PCO2 levels back to physiological range. Patients are started on oxygen, but endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation might be required in patients with severe acidosis.

questions.text: You are working as an intern in the ENT department. During the ward rounds, the HOD asks you to show the pure tone audiometry of a patient, who was diagnosed with left-sided otosclerosis. Which of the following graphs you would show to the HOD?
questions.solution:
Graph C represents the pure tone audiometry (PTA) of a patient with left-sided otosclerosis and has the following features:

  • A dip in the bone conduction curve of the left ear with a maximum dip at 2000 Hz called Carhart’s notch.
  • Air conduction is poor & worse for lower frequencies.
  • A large air-bone gap is seen

PTA is interpreted by:

  • Blue color PTA is indicative of the left ear and red color for the right ear.
  • [ and ] indicate right and left bone conduction respectively.
  • O and X indicate right and left air conduction respectively.

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which the normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. The lesion starts in an area called fissula ante fenestram just in front of the oval window. Patients complain of hearing loss, that they hear better in noisy environments (Paracusis willisii), and tinnitus. On examination, a red blush of the tympanic membrane due to vascularity can be seen known as Schwartze sign. Surgical intervention by stapedectomy/stapedotomy is the mainstay of treatment.

Other options:

  • Graph A shows a dip in the bone conduction curve of the right ear and is seen in right-sided otosclerosis.
  • Graph B and graph D shows a dip in the air conduction curve.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: A known HIV-positive patient presents with dry cough and dyspnea. The chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial pneumonia with pneumatoceles. Special staining of the bronchoalveolar lavage sample shows the following picture. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the staining image are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The most likely causative organism is Pneumocystis jirovecii.

The special staining used here is Gomori’s methamine silver staining. On special staining, the cysts of P. jirovecii resemble black-coloured crushed ping pong balls.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive or productive of only scant amounts of white sputum. The chest X-ray is either normal or shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of a dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

 

 

The standard treatment for PCP is trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. Prophylaxis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is recommended for HIV patients with CD4<200/mm3.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The given strip of ECG shows a Wenckebach/Mobitz type I block, a type of second-degree AV block.

In this type of heart block, there is a progressive lengthening of the PR interval with each beat, and then there is a loss of conduction which manifests as a dropped beat. This is characterized by a P wave without a QRS complex. Then the same pattern repeats. The PR interval immediately after a dropped wave is shorter than the PR interval immediately before it.

Types of Heart Block

1. First-degree Heart Block: Prolonged PR interval, > 0.2 s, RR interval equal and constant

 

2. Second-degree Heart Block: missed QRS due to intermitted failure of conduction between the atria and the ventricles.

  • Mobitz type I/ Wenckebach: Progressive prolongation of the PR interval followed by a missed QRS complex.

 

  • Mobitz type II: Fixed PR interval but a QRS wave is missed after every few normally conducted QRS waves.

 

3. Third-degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

Here, the atria fail to conduct impulses to the ventricles. This leads to an escape ventricular rhythm. The number of atrial contraction waves (P wave) will be higher than the ventricular contraction waves (R wave). The intervals between two consecutive P waves or R waves will be constant, but there is no relationship between them.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who worked as a miner for the past 25 years, comes to the OPD with complaints of dyspnoea and cough. Routine blood work-up, pulmonary function tests, and a lung biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis. The histopathological examination of the sample is shown below. Which type of emphysema can this condition give rise to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and microscopic image show abundant black pigment within the macrophages of lung parenchyma, which is characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis/coal worker's pneumoconiosis and may give rise to centrilobular emphysema.

The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then accumulate in the connective tissue along the lymphatics or in lymphoid tissue along the bronchi or the hilum, blackening the tissues. Aggregates of carbon dust present as coal macules or nodules, which consist of carbon-laden macrophages.

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high air pollution and carbon particles, such as coal mines. Coal worker's pneumoconiosis is usually benign, and less than 10% of cases develop progressive massive fibrosis, which may lead to pulmonary dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale.

Coal workers may also develop emphysema or chronic bronchitis, independent of smoking. Unlike asbestosis, this condition does not predispose to cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Panacinar emphysema is caused by alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. It affects the entire acinus and primarily involves the lower lobes. It is not related to occupational exposures like mining but rather a genetic enzyme deficiency that leads to lung damage, making it an unlikely cause in this patient.

Option C: Paraseptal emphysema involves distal acinar destruction, often affecting subpleural areas. It is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults. Since this condition is not linked to prolonged dust exposure or mining, it is not the correct answer for this case.

Option D: Irregular emphysema occurs secondary to lung scarring, often due to previous infections or fibrosis rather than occupational lung diseases.

questions.text: A patient with COPD presented with pneumothorax and was managed with tube thoracostomy. Even after 3 days, the water-seal drain showed continuous air bubbles. Chest radiograph showed a failure of the expansion of the lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Apply suction to the chest drain

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a persistent air leak (>72 hours) and failure of the lung to expand fully after tube thoracostomy for a patient with pneumothorax. For such patients, thoracic surgical intervention is recommended.

Indications for surgical intervention for pneumothorax include:

  • Second ipsilateral pneumothorax
  • First contralateral pneumothorax
  • Bilateral spontaneous pneumothorax
  • Pneumothorax fails to settle despite chest drainage
  • Spontaneous haemothorax in professionals at risk (like pilots and divers)
  • Pregnancy

Pneumothorax can be termed as spontaneous if the visceral pleura ruptures without any external cause such as trauma. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax occurs without any prior history of lung disease. It is usually seen in young patients and occurs due to leaks from bullae present in the upper lobe of the lungs. If the patient has a prior history of COPD, cystic fibrosis, or any other bullous disease of the lung that led to the pneumothorax, it is called secondary spontaneous pneumothorax.

The management of pneumothorax is based on the rim size — the distance between the edge of the chest wall and the lung margin.

If it is a primary pneumothorax:

  • If the rim size is <2 cm and there are no symptoms, the patient is just observed and then discharged. The patient is reviewed in the OPD in 2-4 weeks.
  • If the rim size is >2 cm or there are symptoms such as breathlessness, aspiration of the air using a 16-18G cannula is done and then the patient is reviewed in the OPD in 2-4 weeks.

If it is a secondary pneumothorax:

  • If the rim size is <2 cm and there are no symptoms, aspiration of the air using a 16-18G cannula is done and then the patient is put on high-flow oxygen and observed for the next 24 hours. 
  • If the rim size is >2 cm or there are symptoms such as breathlessness, a tube thoracostomy (insertion of a chest drain) is done.

Surgery for pneumothorax can be performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) or as an open procedure (thoracotomy). The aim is to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura to contain any subsequent leaks and prevent lung collapse. Pleural adhesion is achieved by:

  1. Pleurectomy: stripping the parietal pleura from the chest wall.
  2. Pleural abrasion: scraping off the slick surface of the parietal pleura.
  3. Chemical pleurodesis: using talc to make the two layers of the pleura adherent to each other.

questions.text: False statement regarding scar dehiscence is

choices.text: Disruption of part of scar and not the entire length
Uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous
Bleeding is almost nil or minimal

questions.solution:
The uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous in case of scar rupture and not dehiscence.

Scar dehiscence is the asymptomatic separation of the uterine scar without the involvement of the peritoneal coat. It is characterized by:

  • Only a part of the scar is disrupted and not the entire length (Option A)
  • The fetal membranes are intact (Option B)
  • Almost nil or minimal bleeding (Option D)

Scar rupture is characterized by the complete separation of all the uterine layers including the serosa. It is characterized by:

  • The entire length of the scar is disrupted
  • Rupture of the membranes with varying amounts of bleeding from the margins or from its extension
  • The uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous

questions.text: A young male patient with no history of prior liver disease is diagnosed with fibrolamellar variant of hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following is likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Fibrolamellar variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is likely to be associated with elevated levels of neurotensin. 

Fibrolamellar variant of HCC occurs in young patients without any history of cirrhosis. The tumor is well-demarcated and may have a central fibrotic area. Histology shows large tumor cells embedded in a fibrous stroma which is arranged in bundles or lamellae. The fibrolamellar variant does not produce AFP.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in NICU. The consultant asks you to monitor the pre and post ductal SpO2 readings for a baby with cyanotic heart disease. The conventional way of measuring pre and post-ductal saturation(SpO2) respectively is?

choices.text: Both measured from the right hand before and after giving oxygen for 10 minutes

questions.solution:
The site for measuring preductal and post ductal SpO2 readings has to be hand and foot respectively. The conventional way is to use the right hand and one of the feet. 

The pre-ductal SpO2 essentially implies measuring saturation before ductus arteriosus joins and post-ductal implies measuring saturation after ductus arteriosus joins aorta. This is so because, if ductus arteriosus is patent, it allows the mixing of de-oxygenated blood causing a fall in oxygen saturation measured distal to the mixing site.

 The ductus arteriosus is generally attached after the left subclavian branches out. Hence measuring saturation from hands (supplied by subclavian artery on either side) and feet (supplied by branches and continuation of abdominal aorta) should be done.

The difference in the saturation of more than 10% conveys the significant right to left shunt.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with P1L1 presents with tiredness and sweating. She delivered a healthy male baby 4 weeks ago through vaginal delivery. However, she had excessive blood loss and was transfused with 4 units of packed cells post-delivery. She also mentions that she has reduced milk secretion. Which of the following is the most life-threatening complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman presenting with fatigue, sweating, and failure of lactation, following a massive post-partum hemorrhage is suggestive of Sheehan syndrome causing panhypopituitarism. Adrenal insufficiency, due to a decrease in the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) which results in decreased cortisol, is the most  life-threatening complication in this patient.

Pituitary ischemia and necrosis leading to panhypopituitarism following severe hypotension due to a massive postpartum hemorrhage is known as Sheehan syndrome. The increased risk for pituitary hemorrhage and infarction is attributed to the hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary during pregnancy. 

It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterised by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage and death.

Also it can present late with the following features:

  • Lactation failure due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Loss of sexual and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids followed by thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin, and growth hormones

questions.text: A heavy weight lifter complains of low backache for 3 months. On examination there is asymmetric motor and sensory loss in the lower limbs with absent knee and ankle jerks. Bowel and bladder functions are normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is cauda equina syndrome. 

Cauda equina syndrome refers to an injury to the lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal, occurring distal to the termination of spinal cord at L1-L2 level. It occurs most commonly due to rupture of lumbosacral intervertebral disc. Other causes include lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within spinal canal, and compressive mass lesions such as tumors.

The patients present with low back ache (most often a radicular type of pain), lower limb weakness and sensory loss, and areflexia in the lower limbs. Relative sparing of bowel and bladder functions with late-onset retention symptoms is seen. Treatment is with urgent surgical decompression of the involved area.

Other options :

Option A: Central cord syndrome results from selective damage to gray matter cells and spinothalamic tracts, which are present in the vicinity of the central canal. It occurs due to syringomyelia (cervical cord involvement), spinal trauma and intrinsic tumors of the spinal cord. Patients with cervical cord involvement present with weakness in arms more than legs and loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders, upper back and nape of the neck (cape-like distribution). Fine touch, vibration, and joint position sense remain preserved.

Option B: Patients with Brown-Séquard syndrome present with:

  • Ipsilateral weakness due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibration sense due to the involvement of the posterior column tracts.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.

Option D: Patients with conus medullaris syndrome present with bilateral saddle anesthesia, prominent bowel and bladder dysfunction, and impotence. While knee jerk is often preserved, they have a loss of bulbocavernosus and anal reflexes.

questions.text: A woman came to the police station with complaints of domestic abuse and showed multiple bruises on her arms which were dark brown in color, with multiple vesicles, itching, and redness in the surrounding area. The shape of the bruise was irregular and the margins were well-defined. There was no typical change in the color of the bruise with the passage of time. Which of the following is the least likely to produce such lesions?
questions.solution:
The bruise located in an accessible area, associated with blisters, itching, and no color change is suggestive of an artificial bruise which is unlikely to be caused by  

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances such as the juice of marking nut, Calotropis, or Plumbago rosea to simulate true bruises. However, the following features can be used to distinguish between the two categories.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible parts Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time
Shape Irregular Rounded
Margins Well-defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles Present Absent
Redness/ Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Chemical tests Positive Negative

Semecarpus Anacardium commonly known as marking nut produces injuries that stimulate contusion. The active principles are semicarpol and bhilawanol.

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. Seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. When taken orally, it can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnoea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death.

The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours. The bruised nut is applied to the cervical os for criminal abortion. The juice can be used by malingerers to produce ophthalmia. Accidental poisoning may result from the administration of juice internally by quacks.

The image below shows marking nut:

The Calotropis plant is identified by the presence of purple or white flowers. The active principles of the plants are uscharin, calotoxin, calactin, and calotropin. The juice of the plant can be used to produce artificial bruises, introduced into the uterus on an abortion stick for criminal abortion, and occasionally used as an arrow poison.

The image given below shows Calotropis:

 

 

The root of Plumbago rosea contains an active principle plumbagin. Applied externally it causes blisters and irritation. While consumed it causes burning pain from mouth to stomach, vomiting, thirst, diarrhea, collapse, and death.

The active principles of Abrus precatorius are abrin, abrine, and abralin. It is a commonly used cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as Sui (meaning needle in Hindi). These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles, and used to kill cattle.
