questions.text: A 15-month-old baby was brought to the OPD with a history of self-injurious behavior. Past medical history is significant for multiple episodes of seizures. Labs reveal increased plasma tyrosine levels. Urine metabolic screening reveals the presence of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites. Enzyme studies reveal a deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase. Which of the following inborn errors of metabolism is the child suffering from?
questions.solution:
Primary deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) causes hereditary tyrosinemia type 3. The diagnosis is suspected in children with sustained moderate increases in plasma levels of tyrosine (typically 350-700 µmol/L on a normal diet) and the presence of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids in urine.

Asymptomatic infants with 4-HPPD deficiency have been identified by neonatal screening for hypertyrosinemia. In symptomatic patients, developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia, and self-injurious behavior have been reported. Liver and renal abnormalities are absent.

Treatment principally includes a low-protein diet and vitamin C.

Other options

Option A: Type 1 tyrosinemia

Type 1 tyrosinemia is the most common form of tyrosinemia caused by defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme. They usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin-D-resistant rickets.

Boiled cabbage odor may be present in classical type 1 tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.

Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine is diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia. Tyrosinemia type 1 is treated with nitisinone and a diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine. Rarely, patients treated with nitisinone may develop corneal crystals of tyrosine which can be reduced by strict dietary control.

Option B: Tyrosinemia II tyrosinemia:

Richner-Hanhart syndrome or oculocutaneous tyrosinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase and presents with ocular manifestations like excessive tearing, redness, pain, photophobia, herpetiform corneal ulcers, intellectual disability and painful, nonpruritic hyperkeratotic plaques on the soles, palms, and fingertips.

Option C: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). This causes increased de novo purine synthesis and excessive amounts of uric acid. Patients present with self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history, and hyperuricemia

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child is hypotonic and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated blood uric acid levels, and marked lactic acidosis. The infant is likely to be deficient in
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia) or glucose 6-phosphate translocase deficiency (type Ib).

Signs and symptoms include

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia 
  • Elevated blood uric acid levels 
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch 
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Allopurinol should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Hers disease (GSD VI). Patients usually present in early childhood with hepatomegaly and growth retardation. Lactic acid and uric acid levels are normal.

Option B: Phosphorylase kinase deficiency leads to Type IX GSD. Phosphorylase kinase is involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis. It presents in the first 2 years of life with short stature and hepatomegaly. Unlike GSD I, lactic acidosis, bleeding tendency, and loose bowel movements are not characteristic.

Option C: Liver glycogen synthase deficiency leads to Type 0 GSD. It presents in infancy with early-morning drowsiness, pallor, vomiting, fatigue, and sometimes convulsions. Hypoglycemia, hyperketonemia, and low lactate levels are seen. There is no hyperlipidemia or hepatomegaly.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case?
questions.solution:
The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells. 

Korner’s septum is a bony plate that separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells. Mastoid antrum can only be reached after the Korner’s septum is removed. Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not identified.

questions.text: An elderly man was admitted to the hospital with high-grade fever and night sweats along with productive cough. He also mentions that he has lost weight. He is a chronic alcoholic and smoker. His sputum sample was collected for Modified acid-fast stain and revealed the following. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
The organism shown in the image is the Nocardia asteroides. They are modified acid-fast positive and appear as branching, filamentous rods. Patients with nocardiosis usually present with symptoms mimicking tuberculosis, such as fever, cough, night sweats.  

Nocardia are gram-positive strict aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections mostly in the immunocompromised.

Pleuropulmonary nocardiosis is the main presentation and usually manifests as pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, cough with or without sputum production, and shortness of breath.

Hematogenous spread from the lung is most frequently to the brain. Other common sites include skin, kidneys, bones, muscles, and eyes, but almost any organ can be involved. Cutaneous infection may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, lymphocutaneous lesions or actinomycotic mycetoma.

Treatment- Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice.

Other options:

Option A - Mycobacteria tuberculosis is acid-fast but does not have branching filaments.

Option B - Actinomyces israelii is not acid-fast.

Option C - Corynebacterium diphtheriae is not acid-fast.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring the disinfection of wells in a city to reduce the spread of water-borne illnesses. 30 grams of bleaching powder was required to disinfect 2275 liters of well water. When measuring the chlorine demand with the Horrocks apparatus for this well water, which cup would have shown the blue color after adding the indicator?
questions.solution:
Horrocks apparatus used to measure chlorine demand of water. The 3rd cup would have shown a blue color for it to require 30 grams of bleaching powder to disinfect 2275 liters of well water.

Since 2275/455=5, the amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is 30/5=6 grams

To calculate the dose of bleaching required to disinfect 455 liters of water, the formula is (n×2), We know the dose required, and we have to calculate 'n' (n represents the position of the cup which was first to show the color).

6=n×2, therefore n=3.

The third cup would have turned blue upon adding the indicator.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 45-year-old businessman presents to your OPD with complaints of insomnia. His job requires frequent travel to foreign countries and he always has a jet lag issue. Which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate for his treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes transient sleep disorder which includes jet lag and shift work transition. The best and most effective pharmacological agent against this situation is ramelteon. 

Ramelteon:

Ramelteon is a melatonin receptor agonist acting directly on MT1 and MT2 mediated G-protein coupled receptors and induces sleep. It is considered to be more effective than melatonin. It is safer than melatonin as it has no addiction liability. It is less effective than benzodiazipines. It has a half-life of 5 hours.

Ramelteon is metabolized by CYP450 enzyme system and should not be taken along with drugs or substances inhibiting CYPA12 enzyme (ciprofloxacin, zileuton, and fluvoxamine) and Flucanazole (CYP2C9). It should be cautiously used with rifampin, an enzyme inducer. This can lead on to decreased function.

Side effects include dizziness, fatigue, somnalesence, and an increase in prolactin levels. Ramelteon undergoes extensive first pass metabolism its bioavailability is less than 2%.

Its congener family includes: 

  • Tasimelteon used for treatment of chronic sleep disorders like the non 24-hours sleep wake disorder. It is also used to treat insomnia in blind people. 
  • Agomelatine along with MT1 and MT2 agonistic activity has 5HT2c antagonistic activity and thus is approved for treatment of major depressive disorder with insomnia. 

Other options:

Option A: Zolpidem belongs to novel benzodiazepine receptor agonists called Z compounds. It binds to the BZD receptor present on the GABA receptor chloride channel complex.

Option B: Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice in narcolepsy which is characterized by the tetrad of:

  • Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  • Hypnagogic hallucinations
  • Sleep paralysis

questions.text: The results of a meta-analysis of various studies on the relationship between rabies infection and mortality rates are plotted as shown in the image below. What is this graphical representation known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a funnel plot, which is a means to assess the extent to which a systematic review is influenced by publication and other biases.

In general, there will be more variability in the results of smaller studies than larger studies, so, this plot should look like an inverted funnel. The larger study results cluster around the overall mean effect more closely than the results of the smaller studies. A funnel plot displays the effect size plotted against the sample size.

If the distribution of results of smaller studies is asymmetrical, it suggests that some smaller studies that showed unfavorable results may be missing from the analysis because of various biases. An asymmetrical funnel plot shows the apparent presence of publication bias. 

Other options :

Option B: Forest plots are commonly used to present the results of meta-analyses. It allows the results to be seen at a glance, with ready identification of outliers.

The following image shows a generic forest plot showing the odds ratios of various studies, their confidence intervals, and the summary measure arrived at through meta-analysis.

Option C: Scattergram is a graphical representation of the bivariate distribution relationship between two correlated variables. Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. This is expressed in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient and its direction is indicated by the sign. 

The image below shows a scattergram.

Option D- An ogive is a cumulative frequency polygon that forms a typical S-shaped curve.

The following image shows an example of an ogive.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.
  • A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.
  • These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.
  • In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 14-year-old professional sports player presents with complaints of pain in the upper limb on lifting weights. During the clinical examination of this patient,  you ask to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Now, wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle. Which of the following conditions should you suspect?
questions.solution:
The Cozen's test has been performed and produces pain over the lateral epicondyle which is positive in tennis elbow - lateral epicondylitis.

Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) is tendinopathy characterized by pain arising from the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) at the lateral epicondyle. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at the origin during activities that involve repeated forceful wrist extension and supination (Eg: backhand in tennis and use of a screwdriver). 

Patients present with outer elbow pain, radiating down the forearm and along with morning stiffness of the elbow. The pain is often aggravated by lifting objects and shaking hands. The elbow may appear normal or have slight swelling, with a full range of movement.

Tenderness is present over the lateral epicondyle. Clinical tests for tennis elbow are:

  • Cozen's test: Resisted extension of the wrist with the elbow in full extension elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley’s test: extension of the middle finger against resistance elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mill's sign: Extension of the elbow in pronation with a flexed wrist elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents to the clinic with midline swelling in the neck. He recently had an episode of sore throat, following which the swelling became painful and red. The swelling moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion. Which of the following is the definitive management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst. Sistrunk's operation is the definitive management for this condition.

Thyroglossal cysts represent the persistence of the tract through which the thyroid gland descends from the base of the tongue to the lower part of the neck. The definitive management of a thyroglossal cyst involves the excision of this tract. This includes the removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and the suprahyoid tract from the base of the tongue (foramen cecum) to the vallecula along with a core of normal tissue from either side. This process is known as Sistrunk's operation. 

Thyroglossal duct cysts present as a midline neck swelling that moves upwards with swallowing and tongue protrusion. They can become infected when an upper respiratory tract infection spreads to the cyst. During such episodes, they may burst onto the surface of the skin, leading to the formation of a thyroglossal fistula.

The recurrence rate with simple excision (option B) is far higher than Sistrunk's operation, so it is not preferred. Total thyroidectomy (option D) is only indicated if papillary thyroid carcinoma has developed in the thyroglossal cyst. There is no role of percutaneous aspiration (option A) in the definitive management of thyroglossal cysts.

questions.text: Identify the laryngoscopic blade given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of the Macintosh laryngoscopic blade, an instrument that allows for laryngeal examination and tracheal intubation. It is the most commonly used laryngoscopic blade for endotracheal intubation in adults.

Laryngoscopic blades can be:

  • Curved  - Macintosh
  • Straight - Miller

Miller is the most commonly used blade in infants.

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

The tip of the curved Macintosh blade is placed in the vallecula after the tongue is slid leftward and anteriorly. The laryngoscope handle is lifted in a forward and upward direction (stretching the hyoepiglottic ligament). This causes the epiglottis to move upward, eventually exposing the vocal cords.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by a 'ray pattern' where all joints of the same digit are involved while the adjacent digit is spared or a 'row pattern' when there is a predilection for the distal interphalangeal joint and sparing of the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
In psoriatic arthritis, joint involvement tends to follow 'ray' and 'row' patterns. Ray distribution refers to the involvement of all the joints of one finger while the adjacent finger is totally spared. Row pattern is predilection for the distal interphalangeal joint and sparing of the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age. The disease is equally prevalent in males & females. Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints. Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). The distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is the most common joint involved in psoriatic arthritis. 

 

 A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis, or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

  1. Current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis
  2. Typical psoriatic nail involvement
  3. Rheumatoid factor negative
  4. Current or history of dactylitis
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Triggers include trauma to a joint or tendon (Koebner effect), smoking, alcohol excess, and HIV infection. 

Clinical features include:

  • Asymmetric joint involvement - most common presentation
  • Early morning stiffness
  • Swollen, tender, one or more joints
  • Enthesitis: Heel pain due to Achilles tendon inflammation
  • Plantar fasciitis
  • Dactylitis/ sausage fingers with telescoping (shortening of toes due to osteolysis)
  • Nail changes: hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
  • Axial involvement may occur

Inflammatory markers like CRP and ESR are elevated. Plain x‐rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease, showing:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'

NSAIDs, steroid injections, methotrexate, and cyclosporin/ biologicals can be used for the management of this condition. Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Psoriatic arthritis is found to be associated with ocular diseases like conjunctivitis, uveitis, iridocyclitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca and cataracts, obesity/ metabolic syndrome, alcohol misuse, and premature cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the inverse stretch reflex?

choices.text: The alpha motor neurons are activated
The receptor is golgi tendon organ
It is innervated by type 1b sensory fibres

questions.solution:
In the inverse stretch reflex, there is inhibition of alpha motor neurons which results in muscle relaxation.

Up to a physiological limit, the harder a muscle is stretched, the stronger the contraction. However, when the tension becomes too great and can cause damage to the muscle fibers, the contraction suddenly stops and the muscle relaxes. This is known as the inverse stretch reflex. 

The receptor for the inverse stretch reflex is the Golgi tendon organ. It lies in series with the muscle fibers and is stimulated by passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle, but mainly the latter. The Golgi tendon organ is innervated by type Ib sensory fibers. These fibers synapse with an inhibitory interneuron which terminates on the motor neuron innervating the same muscle. The inverse stretch reflex is thus disynaptic. Stimulation of the Golgi tendon organ brings about the relaxation of the muscle.

Note: Reflex arcs in which interneurons are interposed between the afferent and efferent neurons are called polysynaptic reflexes. There can be anywhere from two to hundreds of synapses in a polysynaptic reflex arc. Here, bisynpatic reflex is also considered a polysynaptic reflex.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is diagnosed with schizophrenia is brought by his wife to the hospital. His wife says that he talks about suicidal ideas and has attempted suicide once. The psychiatrist changes the medication to clozapine. During the follow-up after a month, the patient says that his pillow is completely soaked with saliva in the mornings. What is the mechanism by which clozapine causes soaking of the pillow?
questions.solution:
M4 agonism is the mechanism by which clozapine causes soaking of the pillow. This is called 'wet pillow syndrome' in which there is hypersalivation. Pirenzepine, an M4 antagonist alleviates sialorrhea.

Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is an antagonist of 5HT2A, D1, D3, D4, and α-receptors. Clozapine is used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia, suicidal patients with schizophrenia, severe psychotic depression, and Huntington's disease.  

Adverse effects of clozapine are:

  • Sedation and weight gain- H1 antagonism
  • Syncope, tachycardia, hypotension- α1 antagonism
  • Hypersalivation/sialorrhea- M4 agonism
  • Seizures- dose-dependant
  • Agranulocytosis- dose-independent

The patient who is on clozapine should undergo regular hematological monitoring for the risk of agranulocytosis. Avoid combining clozapine with other agranulocytosis-causing drugs like carbamazepine, phenytoin, propylthiouracil, sulfonamides.

Clozapine reduces the seizure threshold thus increasing the risk of seizures.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented with fatigue, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Investigations revealed hemoglobin levels of 9 g/dL and orotic acid crystalluria. Peripheral blood smear showed a large number of hypochromic macrocytes. Other red cells were microcytic and hypochromic. Serum folate, B12 levels, and blood ammonia levels appeared normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia with orotic acid crystalluria is consistent with orotic aciduria, a disorder of pyrimidine metabolism.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Treatment includes, administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anemia, reduces orotic acid excretion, and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

Causes of megaloblastic anemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/partial gastrectomy, ileal resection, Crohn's disease
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine)
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

Other options:
Option (A): B12 metabolic defect is unlikely since B12 and folate levels are normal.
Option (B): Urea cycle defect is also unlikely because the blood ammonia levels are normal.
Option (C): Purine metabolism disorders include gouty arthritis, adenosine deaminase deficiency, and purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient, who appears as female phenotypically presents with complaints of amenorrhoea.  On further examination, the patient has poorly developed breasts and normal-looking female external genitalia. Ultrasound of the pelvis shows a normally developed vagina, uterus, and fallopian tubes but, the presence of ovaries could not be ensured. The karyotype of the patient was found to be 46 XY. Which of the following statements is true about the condition?

choices.text: Pregnancy is possible in these patients
This syndrome is female pseudohermaphrodite type
It is impossible to induce menstruation in these patients
Hormone replacement therapy has no role in treating them

questions.solution:
The possible diagnosis from the given symptoms and signs is 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis, Swyer syndrome. Pregnancy is possible in these patients. As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in these patients with 46 XY karyotype, who are actually determined to be males, the following features are seen

  • Normal development of female internal genitalia, as the poorly developed gonads, cannot produce the Anti-Mullerian Hormone(AMH).
  • Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characters, as the default gonads, cannot produce the sex hormones.

Points to be considered while treating these patients:

  • Cyclical estrogen and progesterone can induce menstruation
  • As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.
  • Tumours can develop in the streak gonads and hence they have to be removed prophylactically
  • Hormonal replacement therapy also has a role in maintaining the bone health of these patients
  • Genetic counselling has to be offered to the affected individuals and their family members.

Swyer syndrome is a type of male pseudohermaphrodite.

questions.text: Which of the following is decreased in haemolytic anaemia?
questions.solution:
Haptoglobin levels decrease in hemolytic anemia.

Haptoglobin is synthesized by the liver. It binds to free hemoglobin and prevents its excretion in urine. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex is rapidly destroyed by the mononuclear phagocytes. Hence, haptoglobin levels decrease in the presence of free hemoglobin as seen in hemolytic anemia.

LDH, free Hb, and methemoglobin are elevated in hemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?

choices.text: It is an example of prion disease
It is associated with fever and leukocytosis

questions.solution:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) does not show an inflammatory response, so fever and leukocytosis are characteristically absent.

CJD is a prion disease. The term prion refers to an infectious particle composed of proteins without any nucleic acids. They are misfolded proteins that are resistant to degradation and can induce similar misfolding in other proteins. Normal PrPC protein (predominant α-helix) gets converted to pathogenic PrPSc protein (predominant β-structure).

Most cases of CJD are sporadic in origin. Acquired CJD includes iatrogenic and variant subtypes. Iatrogenic CJD occurs due to dura mater grafts or therapy with contaminated growth hormone, while the variant subtype is acquired following ingestion of tainted beef. Familial cases of CJD are known to occur, but are rare. 

Patients present with non-specific symptoms such as headache, anxiety, and weight loss initially. This is followed by a rapidly evolving loss of higher cortical function leading to dementia. Important associated symptoms include psychosis and visual hallucinations, apathy, insomnia, and depression. Majority of the patients with CJD develop myoclonus which persists when the patient is asleep. Startle myoclonus can be elicited by loud sounds.

Sporadic CJD is characterized by increased intensity of basal ganglia and cortical ribboning on the FLAIR sequence of MRI as shown in the image below. 

 

EEG shows generalized high-voltage triphasic waves, but they are usually transient as shown below.

 

The patient does not have a fever, raised ESR, leukocytosis, or increased CSF cell counts. The presence of these should prompt a diagnosis other than CJD. There is no effective treatment for CJD, and most patients succumb within 12 months of the onset of the symptoms.

questions.text: What is the frequency at which the post-placement medical examination should be done in an individual whose occupational exposure is related to the symbol shown below?
questions.solution:
The symbol signifies radiation hazard, the post-placement medical examination in radiation industry workers is done at a frequency of once in 2 months or 6 times a year.

  • Daily examination is done for Dichromate exposure
  • Monthly for lead, dye exposure
  • Annual medical examination is done for most other occupational exposures.

questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following clinical features is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of Kwashiorkor. Flaky paint dermatosis is seen in this condition.

The skin abnormalities include increased pigmentation, shedding of skin cells, and dyspigmentation. The pigmentation may appear as overlapping patches resembling peeling paint.

Skin changes which typically occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath that are easily infected, known as flaky paint dermatosis.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema. The edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs. It quickly develops into generalized edema affecting also the hands, arms, and face (moon face). 

The hair is sparse and easily pulled out and may lose its curl. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish, with alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand, known as flag sign. Children with edema are apathetic and often refuse to eat.

Simian facies, loose wrinkled skin, baggy pant appearance, and alert child with no edema are characteristic features of marasmus.

questions.text: A young patient presented with fever and pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. USG shows a single abscess in the right lobe of the liver. Serology is positive for anti-amebic antibodies. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Positive serology for anti-amebic antibodies in a patient with fever and pain in the right upper quadrant suggests a diagnosis of amebic liver abscess. The most appropriate treatment for this is medical therapy with metronidazole and diloxanide.

Liver abscess is the most common extraintestinal manifestation of amebiasis. It can occur in patients with an evident history of colitis, but most commonly presents without any antecedent history related to the GIT. Patients present with fever, abdominal pain, and tender hepatomegaly. Heavy alcohol consumption is an important risk factor for the development of amebic liver abscesses.

Since USG abdomen cannot reliably differentiate between pyogenic and amebic liver abscesses, the mainstay of the diagnosis is in detecting anti-amebic antibodies in the blood by enzyme immunoassays. Examination of the stools for the organisms and the antigens is mostly negative. Image-guided aspiration of the fluid to detect amebic antigens may be used for diagnosis when serological studies are not useful.

The treatment is by metronidazole/tinidazole plus a luminal agent such as diloxanide/iodoquinol/paromomycin. The treatment is curative in >90% of the patients. Therapeutic needle aspiration (option A) has not been found to be any more beneficial than medical therapy. Needle aspiration of the abscess is thus reserved for cases where there is diagnostic uncertainty (testing for antigens) and those with a higher risk of rupture (>5 cm in diameter).

Pig-tail catheter insertion and drainage (option B) is done for the management of pyogenic liver abscess under the cover of antibiotics. Puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR) therapy is done for the management of hydatid cyst of the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ethambutol?

choices.text: Does not require dose modification in patients with renal failure
Ethambutol decreases arabinogalactan biosynthesis by inhibiting arabinosyltransferase III
Loss of red-green discrimination may occur as a side effect
Optic nerve recovers when ethambutol intake is stopped

questions.solution:
The major route of excretion of Ethambutol is via the renal route. Hence it requires dose reduction in renal disease. 

Ethambutol can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green color blindness. Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral. The intensity of the visual difficulty is related to the duration of therapy. Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended. Recovery usually occurs on stopping ethambutol.

Ethambutol is used for the treatment of TB, disseminated MAC, and in M. kansasii infection. It inhibits arabinosyltransferase III, thereby disrupting the transfer of arabinose into arabinogalactan biosynthesis which in turn disrupts the assembly of the mycobacterial cell wall. Resistance occurs due to mutations in the embB gene.

Since 80% of the drug is eliminated through the kidney unchanged, its dosing should be decreased in renal failure to avoid toxicity. Therefore, in renal failure, ethambutol should be given 15-25 mg/kg three times a week, instead of daily.

Other side effects are pruritus, joint pain, GI upset, abdominal pain, malaise, headache, dizziness, mental confusion, disorientation, possible hallucinations, and decreased renal excretion of uric acid.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with HIV was brought to the hospital with complaints of persistent diarrhoea and fever for the last month. The examination of the oral cavity was as given below. What is the most probable stage of the disease the child is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with HIV, and persistent diarrhea and fever with oral candidiasis (as given in the image) suggests stage 3 of HIV infection. 

Features of Stage 3 of the disease include 

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)
  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis
  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Clinical features of HIV infection are highly variable. Initial signs and symptoms are non-specific like lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent diarrhea, and failure to thrive. The status of the disease may be assessed based on the clinical features and immunological response. 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in babies born to HIV-infected mothers is done by HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program (Early Infant Diagnosis) now uses HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample. According to the national AIDS control organization (NACO), an infant born to an HIV-positive mother should be breastfed exclusively or by replacement feeds exclusively for 6 months of age. If exclusive replacement feeding is done, infants should receive ARV prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine, even if the baby is tested negative.

questions.text: Identify the test being performed.
questions.solution:
The test being performed in the given image is Romberg's test.

While performing Romberg's test, the patient is asked to stand with his feet close together, initially with his eyes open. If the patient is able to maintain their balance with the eyes open, they are asked to close their eyes. If they lose their balance and sway or fall with their eyes closed, the test is said to be positive. The examiner needs to be prepared to support the patient in case they are about to fall. 

Patients with disorders of the posterior column tracts will have impaired proprioception, and will have a positive Romberg's test. If the patient has dizziness or a tendency to fall even with the eyes open, then the lesion is likely to be in the vestibular system or cerebellum, and other relevant tests should be performed.

Other options:

Option B: Dix-Hallpike test is the clinical test done to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The test starts with the patient in the sitting position on a bed. The patient's head is turned 45° to the side being tested. The patient is then rapidly laid back into the bed, with the head slightly extended over the edge of the bed. Dix-Hallpike is shown in the image below.

 

Option C: Retropulsion test or pull test involves the examiner abruptly pulling the patient backward by the shoulders. A normal individual remains upright or regains his balance by taking a maximum of one step backward. A patient with Parkinsonism will take a number of steps backward and might lose his balance altogether. 

Option D: Heel-shin test is done to test cerebellar functions by assessing lower limb coordination. The test is done with the patient lying down on a bed. They are asked to put the heel of one leg onto the shin of the other leg, just below the knee. They are then asked to run the heel down the front of the shin till the dorsum of the foot. Patients with cerebellar lesions will have a tremor when trying to place the heel on the shin, and will be unable to accurately run the heel down the entire length of the shin. Heel-shin test is shown in the images below.

questions.text: Metrorrhagia refers to _______

choices.text: Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding

questions.solution:
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding are referred to as metrorrhagia.

Menstrual cycle irregularities are as follows:

  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs irregularly and at frequent intervals.
  • Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Amenorrhea indicates the absence of menstruation. 
  • Polymenorrhea indicates frequent episodes of menstruation that occur at intervals of 21 days or lesser. 
  • Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>5 days). 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding (usually not excessive) that occurs between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Precocious menstruation is the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
  • Postcoital bleeding is vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (ParaGard) is named so for the 380 mm2 surface area of copper present in this. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A. The IUD frame is made of radiopaque barium sulfate. The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

It acts by continuously releasing copper into the uterine cavity. This copper interferes with sperm transport and fertilization of the egg. If an IUCD is inserted within 5 days (120 hours) after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is highly effective.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe and is scheduled for a right anterior sectionectomy. Which of the following segments have to be removed in the patient?
questions.solution:
In the right anterior sectionectomy, segments V and VIII are removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and the left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

  • Right hepatectomy or right Hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII 
  • Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII 
  • Right anterior sectionectomy- V, VIII 
  • Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII 
  • Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV
  • Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII
  • Left medial sectionectomy- IV

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: Histopathological images of the oesophageal biopsies are given below. What of the following adaptive mechanisms is observed in the epithelium?
questions.solution:
The image shows a replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus by metaplastic glandular epithelium containing intestinal-type goblet cells. The image on the left is Barrett's esophagus with non-dysplasia and on the right is Barrett's esophagus with low-grade dysplasia. The adaptive mechanism that is observed here is metaplasia.

Metaplasia is a reversible transformation where a differentiated cell type, either epithelial or mesenchymal, is replaced by another cell type. It serves as an adaptive reaction, where a cell type susceptible to specific stress is substituted by another cell type that can better endure unfavorable conditions. The most frequent form of epithelial metaplasia is the transition from columnar to squamous cells, which can be observed in the respiratory tract as a response to persistent irritation.

 

Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type. Represents an adaptive response in which one cell type that is sensitive to a particular stress is replaced by another cell type that is better able to withstand the adverse environment. Most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous as occurs in the respiratory tract in response to chronic irritation.

questions.text: A patient with a history of renal calculi has been on a low calcium diet for several weeks. On further investigation, which of the following is the most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely finding in this patient would be elevated levels of parathormone (PTH).

A diet low in calcium eventually leads to hypocalcemia, which stimulates PTH release. Hence, this patient will have high PTH levels. 

Increased PTH causes

  • Hypophosphatemia due to increased excretion of phosphate via the kidneys.
  • PTH acts on the kidneys to increase the absorption of calcium.
  • PTH also increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D- 1,25 dihydrocholecalciferol.

In the presence of hypocalcemia, serum calcitonin levels decrease and the active form of vitamin D increases.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she presented with seizures, aphasia, and hemiparesis. Which of the following investigations is useful to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis. This condition can be diagnosed using MR venography.

Cortical vein thrombosis :    

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Prothrombotic conditions

Clinical presentation is highly variable. Headache is the most common symptom. Motor or sensory deficits may be seen. Seizures along with focal deficits in the absence of raised intracranial pressure are suggestive of cortical venous thrombosis. Brain MRI with MR venography is a sensitive investigation to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is admitted with symptoms of ear pain and ear discharge.  A swab was taken and cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe, catalase positive, and shows the following motility. Which of the following is responsible for its pathogenicity?

choices.text: Exotoxin A and a slime layer

questions.solution:
The given clinical features, laboratory findings and the video shows swarming motility of the bacterial growth on a solid agar plate are suggestive of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer are responsible for its pathogenicity. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe, gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown). It shows a positive oxidase reaction and is non-lactose fermenting in nature.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Clinical features - It is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas.

Diagnosis - It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction. 

Other options-

Option A: Shiga toxin acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Shigella dysenteriae causes acute onset of symptoms(fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus which acts via preformed Type A enterotoxin. Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food.

Option D: The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in conversion disorder?
  1. Hemianesthesia
  2. Echolalia
  3. Astasia-abasia
  4. La belle indifference
  5. Waxy flexibility
questions.solution:
The findings seen in conversion disorder are:

  • Hemianesthesia
  • Astasia-abasia
  • La belle indifference

Conversion disorder is also known as functional neurological symptom disorder or dissociative disorder. It includes acute and temporary loss of motor or sensory function without any underlying neurological disease. Because the onset of such symptoms often coincides with psychological issues such as internal conflict, it was speculated that these issues converted to neurological symptoms.

Conversion disorder can present with symptoms such as

  1. Hemianesthesia- Strict half-body split
  2. Paresis and paralysis
  3. Coma
  4. Aphonia
  5. Intractable sneezing
  6. Syncope
  7. Tunnel vision
  8. One of the gait disturbances that can be seen is astasia-abasia — a wildly ataxic, staggering gait with gross and irregular truncal movements and thrashing and waving arm movements. 
  9. La belle indifference refers to a lack of concern towards the symptoms despite the apparent severity of the disability. Although not pathognomonic of conversion disorder, it is often seen in association with it. 

Patients of conversion disorder achieve primary gain by keeping internal conflicts outside of their awareness. These conflicts manifest as physical symptoms. As a result of being sick, the patients are excused from obligations and receive support that might not otherwise have been available. This is referred to as secondary gain. 

The Catatonic syndrome may present with three or more of the following features:

  1. Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  2. Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  3. Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  4. Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  5. Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  6. Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  7. Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  8. Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  9. Agitation: Not influenced by external stimuli
  10. Grimacing
  11. Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  12. Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.

Related Pearl: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment like mutism or blindness
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Primary gain - Unconscious relief from stress as the focus of the patient shifts to the symptoms.
  • Secondary gain - Attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of the symptoms.
  • La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability
  • Astasia abasia - Wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by irregular, jerky truncal movements, thrashing and waving arm movements

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

questions.text: While working on a physiology simulation model to study the pathophysiology of essential hypertension, a researcher observes an increase in heart rate and BP during stimulation of a particular area on the medullary surface. Which of the following structures is he likely to have stimulated?
questions.solution:
Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) acts as the vasomotor/pressor center.

Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is a group of neurons in the pial surface of the medulla, its axons descend down and are present in the intermediolateral column of the spinal cord. It secretes the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate and activates the preganglionic sympathetic fibers. It increases blood pressure and causes tachycardia.

It is negatively regulated by the depressor area/caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) which gets input from baroreceptors.

Remember:

  • RVLM- Rise the HR and BP (pressor area)
  • CVLM- Calms BP (depressor area)

questions.text:
A male patient was given anesthesia for a surgical procedure. After a few minutes, the anesthetist noticed there was a masseter muscle spasm in the patient. His vitals are given below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?
  • Pulse rate - 134/min
  • Blood pressure - 150/90 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate - 28/min
  • Temperature - 102ºF
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of masseter muscle spasm with hyperthermia and elevated blood pressure suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia. The least likely drug to cause this condition is atracurium.

Malignant hyperthermia is a hypermetabolic condition, seen on exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. 

The pathophysiology behind the development of malignant hyperthermia is that there is an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in skeletal muscle. This sudden release of calcium can result in sustained muscle contraction by removing the inhibition of troponin. This leads to increased oxygen consumption, and increased CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia. 

Drugs known to trigger this condition include: 

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, ether, methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine.

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant and is not implicated in malignant hyperthermia.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: The structure marked in the image connects________

choices.text: Orbital surfaces of the temporal lobes
Orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes

questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' is the splenium of the corpus callosum.

The body of the corpus callosum arches posteriorly and ends as the thickened posterior portion called the splenium. The fibers of the splenium form the forceps major, they arch backward into the occipital lobe (striate cortex) and connect the occipital lobes of both sides.

In terms of its anatomical arrangement from anterior to posterior, the corpus callosum consists of four distinct sections: the rostrum, genu, body, and splenium. These sections are responsible for linking specific areas of the cerebral cortex. The isthmus denotes the narrow region situated between the body and splenium at the posterior end of the corpus callosum.

Fibers originating from the genu cross over and give rise to the forceps minor, which establishes connections between frontal cortical regions. The fibers of the body traverse horizontally through the cerebral cortex, forming the corona radiata and other significant white matter pathways. Lastly, the rostral fibers facilitate connections between the orbital regions of the frontal lobes.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P3L3 lady complained of bright red bleeding per vagina 15 days after the vaginal delivery of her 3rd baby. All of the following options could be the likely cause of this bleeding except?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with bright red vaginal bleeding on the 15th day postpartum is secondary postpartum hemorrhage, which can be caused by endometritis, placental polyp, and retained placental cotyledon. Atonic uterus is the most common cause of primary PPH.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) can be subdivided into primary PPH and secondary PPH. Primary PPH is bleeding that occurs within 24 hours of the delivery of the baby. Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurring between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery is called secondary or late PPH.

Causes of primary PPH are atony, trauma, coagulopathy, and retained tissues. The atonic uterus can be caused by numerous factors that interfere with the contraction and retraction of the uterus.

Causes of secondary PPH include:

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

Though retained tissue such as placental cotyledon is the most common cause of secondary PPH, it may interfere with uterine retraction and lead to primary PPH.

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight woman presents with the complaint that she compulsively eats large amounts of food, sometimes even when she is not hungry. Following such episodes, she feels very guilty and uncomfortably full. Most of these episodes occur when she's alone at night. She does not induce vomiting after the episodes.  Which of the following will help reduce such episodes in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to be suffering from bingeeating disorder. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) will help reduce binge-eating episodes. 

CBT has been shown to decrease binge eating episodes as well as the anxiety and depression that accompany this disorder. CBT cannot be used alone in treatment as it does not help with weight loss. Combining CBT with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) has shown good results. 

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Binge-eating disorder:

A. Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both of the following:

1. Eating, in a discrete period, an amount of food that is larger than what most people would eat in a similar period under similar circumstances.

2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).

B. The binge-eating episodes are associated with

1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.

2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.

3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.

4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.

5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

C. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.

D. The binge eating occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.

E. binge eating is not associated with the recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

Binge eating disorder can be classified into mild, moderate, severe, and extreme based on the number of episodes per week:

Severity Episodes/week
Mild 1-3/week
Moderate 4-7/week
Severe 8-13/week
Extreme >14/week

Other options:

Option A - Increased physical activity is a useful way to lose weight because of the increased caloric expenditure. However, it would not reduce the number of binge eating episodes. 

Option B - Hospitalization is the treatment for those with severe anorexia nervosa. This is done to restore nutritional, fluid, and electrolyte status as well as determine a long-term plan of management. 

Option D - Calorie restriction is done in patients who are overweight. However, calorie restriction will not reduce the number of episodes of binge eating.

questions.text:
The serum electrolyte values of a patient are given below. Which of the following should be administered as the first step?

Na+: 138 mEq/L 

K+: 7 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The first step for a patient with hyperkalemia is to give IV calcium gluconate. Only after this the corrective steps to correct potassium levels are taken.

The resting membrane potential of excitable cells is close to the resting membrane potential for K+. In the resting state, there is a constant leakage of K+ out of the cell. If the K+ is higher in the extracellular environment (hyperkalemia), less K+ will leak out of the cell because the gradient is unfavorable. This increases the positive charge inside the cell, leading to the membrane potential being pushed more toward the threshold. In other words, the cell is now more excitable. 

Calcium administration counteracts this by reducing the excitability of the cells and maintaining the membrane potential at the actual resting value. Calcium is administered by intravenous infusion over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. The effect of the infusion lasts for up to 60 minutes. During this time, the steps to correct K+ levels can be taken. These steps include:

  • 10 units of IV insulin followed immediately by 50 mL 50% dextrose bolus
  • Inhaled β2 agonists such as albuterol
  • Cation exchange resins such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate and patiromer can be used for the management of both acute and chronic hyperkalemia
  • Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce K+ concentration

Note that intravenous bicarbonate administration does not have a role in the management of acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is diagnosed to have aortic dissection. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Involvement of only the descending aorta requires emergency surgical repair
Can be associated with Marfan syndrome

questions.solution:
The management of aortic dissection that involves only the descending aorta (Stanford type B) is antihypertensive drugs, not emergency surgery.

Aortic dissection occurs due to the formation of a defect in the intima of the aorta, leading to the tracking of the blood through the layers of the aorta, splitting the medial layer, and thus forming a false lumen. The predisposing factors to aortic dissection include:

  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome and other disorders of connective tissue that can cause degeneration of the tunica media of the aorta, like Ehlers–Danlos syndrome and giant cell arteritis.
  • Pregnancy

The patients present with a sudden onset, tearing interscapular pain with dyspnea. General physical examination may show hypotension or hypertension and loss of pulses. Extension of the dissection in either direction can lead to symptoms related to the organ with compromised perfusion, as given below:

  • Proximal extension can involve head and neck vessels (causing stroke or transient ischemic attack), coronary vessels (causing myocardial infarction) and the root of the aorta (causing aortic regurgitation).
  • Distal extension can involve renal arteries (acute kidney injury), mesenteric arteries (mesenteric ischemia), spinal arteries (paraplegia) and iliac arteries (acute limb ischemia).
  • The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Transesophageal echocardiography can be done at the bedside in patients who are too unstable for transportation. In otherwise stable patients, the diagnosis is established by a CT scan. Depending on the part of the aorta involved, aortic dissections are classified as shown in the image below. 

 

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection (irrespective of the type) is to control hypertension and pain. A β-blocker is used parenterally, such as intravenous esmolol, to control the BP and reduce the heart rate. Sodium nitroprusside can be further added to reduce the systolic pressure to <120 mmHg.

Further management depends on the type of aortic dissection. In Stanford type A dissections, surgical intervention is required. In type B dissections, antihypertensive management is usually enough. Further intervention is indicated in type B dissections if:

  • There is an increase in the pain — which could be a sign of impending rupture
  • Dissection is associated with signs of reduced perfusion of organ or limb

In these complicated type B dissections, percutaneous endovascular stenting is done. Surgery is reserved for patients in whom this procedure fails.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with aortic stenosis?

choices.text: Rapidly rising pulse with sudden collapse
Lateral displacement of the apical impulse

questions.solution:
Aortic stenosis (AS) shows a slow-rising pulse with a delayed peak — this is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. Rapidly rising pulse with sudden collapse (option B) is seen in aortic regurgitation (AR) — this is known as water hammer pulse.

Other examination findings in patients with AS include:

  • A thrill may be palpable on the carotid arteries, more often on the left side.
  • Lateral displacement of the apical impulse (option D).
  • Ejection systolic murmur which increases in intensity to reach a peak towards the middle of ejection (known as crescendo-decrescendo pattern), and ends right before aortic valve closure.
  • Aortic valve closure occurs after pulmonary valve closure, leading to paradoxical splitting of S2 — splitting of S2 in expiration, not in inspiration.
