questions.text: A patient presents with irritation and blurring of vision in both eyes for 1 week. There is a history of penetrating injury to the eye 4 weeks back. What is this finding seen in his fundoscopy image which appears below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sympathetic ophthalmitis and the fundoscopy shows Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium). 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are depicted in the image below.

The exciting eye shows features of low-grade uveitis such as ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. The sympathizing eye is usually involved 4-8 weeks later. It has a prodromal stage with photophobia, ciliary congestion, and keratic precipitates. In the fully developed stage, symptoms of acute iridocyclitis supervene.

Prophylactic measures to be taken before the condition sets in include topical or systemic steroids and antibiotics. Early excision of the injured eye is carried out if it cannot be salvaged. Once sympathetic ophthalmitis has already set in, enucleation of the injured eye must be done. Atropine, immunosuppressants, and corticosteroids should also be administered. 

Other options:

Options A: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. These are seen in Limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They appear as a wall of gelatinous thickening at the limbus

The image below represents Horner-Trantas spots.

Option B: Foster Fuchs spots are degenerative changes in the retina seen in pathological myopia. They are blackish spots due to retinal pigment epithelial hyperplasia that occur as a reparative response to choroidal neovascularization and sub-retinal hemorrhage. Linear breaks in Bruch's membrane, called lacquer cracks, may be seen as fine lines. 

Option D: Roth spots, shown below, are retinal hemorrhages with white centers that are composed of coagulated fibrin. They are seen in acute leukemia, bacteremia (subacute bacterial endocarditis), diabetes, hypertension, and anemia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He underwent immediate amputation surgery of the left lower limb. The postoperative day 2 image is given below. What is the most likely change in peripheral vascular resistance following this surgery?

choices.text: Peripheral vascular resistance is the same
Peripheral vascular resistance cannot be calculated

questions.solution:
The above-given image shows a post-lower limb amputation and the peripheral vascular resistance increases after amputation.

The brain, kidney, muscle, gastrointestinal, skin, and coronary circulations are arranged in parallel circuits. Each tissue contributes to the overall conductance of the systemic circulation. Blood flow through each tissue is a fraction of the cardiac output. It is determined by the resistance and the pressure gradient. Resistance is the reciprocal of conductance.

Amputation of a limb or surgical removal of an organ removes a parallel circuit. This reduces systemic conductance and therefore increases the total peripheral vascular resistance.

Vascular resistance refers to the hindrance to blood flow in vessels. It can be calculated from measurements of blood flow and the pressure difference between two points in a vessel. Blood vessels branch widely to form parallel circuits that supply blood to many organs and tissues of the body. This arrangement permits each tissue to regulate its own blood flow. The total resistance of blood flow is calculated as 1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3

The total resistance of the parallel circuit will be much less than that of any individual blood vessel. An increase in the resistance of any blood vessel in the parallel circuit will increase the total vascular resistance.

questions.text: Which among the following enzymes does not contribute in the reversible phase of the pentose phosphate pathway?
questions.solution:
6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is involved in the irreversible oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway. Transketolase, keto-isomerase, and phosphohexose isomerase are involved in the reversible non-oxidative phase.

The pentose phosphate pathway, also known as the HMP shunt pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It contributes by two major ways:

  • Formation of NADPH for the synthesis of fatty acids and steroids and maintenance of reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity
  • Formation of ribose for the synthesis of nucleic acid and nucleotides

The enzymes for this pathway are found in the cytosol. There are two phases:

  1. Irreversible oxidative phase: Glucose-6-phosphate is dehydrogenated and decarboxylated to form ribulose-5- phosphate.
  2. Reversible nonoxidative phase: Ribulose-5-phosphate is converted back to glucose-6-phosphate.

Clinical significance:

  • Protection against hemolysis: NADPH is utilized for the reduction of oxidized glutathione. Reduced glutathione removes H2O2, thereby preventing oxidative damage to RBCs and hemolysis. Thus, deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase results in hemolytic anemia.
  • Formation of glucoronate: Glucose-6-phosphate gives rise to glucoronate via the uronic acid pathway. Glucoronate is important as a precursor for proteoglycans and as a conjugate for substances like steroid hormones and drugs for their excretion in bile or urine. A deficiency in the uronic acid pathway results in essential pentosuria.
  • Fructose and galactose metabolism: Fructose bypasses the regulatory step in the HMP pathway and undergoes rapid glycolysis in the liver. This results in increased fatty acid synthesis and VLDL secretion. Galactose formed from glucose is an essential constituent of lactose, glycolipids, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. Deficiencies of enzymes in these reactions lead to metabolic diseases like essential fructosuria, hereditary fructose intolerance, and galactosemia.
  • Formation of amino sugars: Amino sugars are formed from glucose and are important components of glycoproteins, glycosphingolipids, and glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse working in the pulmonary department presented with a productive cough and evening rise in temperature for 3 weeks duration. A chest X-ray is done and it shows cavities in the upper lobe. The clinician suspects pulmonary TB and orders a sputum smear examination on two samples which turn out to be negative. He further advises CB-NAAT which reveals Mycobacterium presence but is indeterminate on Rifampicin resistance. What should be done next as per the recent NTEP guidelines?

choices.text: Start treatment as drug sensitive TB and continue Intensive phase for 3 months
Repeat CB-NAAT testing to ascertain drug resistance before initiating treatment
Consider taking fresh sample and test it using line probe assay to detect resistance
Start treatment with MDR TB regimen using oral drugs only for 18 months

questions.solution:
As per the NTEP guidelines, repeat CB-NAAT testing to ascertain drug resistance, needs to be carried out if the first sample tested is Rif indeterminate/inconclusive.

The given case with the typical symptoms of evening rise of temperature and productive cough of more than 2 weeks duration with chest x-ray showing upper lobe cavities prompts a diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis. The initial diagnosis of pulmonary TB is done with sputum smear examination and chest radiography. In this case, despite 2 negative sputum samples, a chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Hence CB-NAAT was performed. 

In cases of high clinical suspicion, Smear is negative but CXR findings are suggestive, or in people with HIV, a CB-NAAT is done. Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification (CBNAAT) detects the presence of Mycobacterium DNA along with resistance against Rifampicin within 2 hours. It analyses sputum or any other biological specimen (except blood and blood-contaminated specimens) using real-time PCR technology

If Rifampicin resistance is absent, it is treated as drug-sensitive TB. If Rifampicin resistance is present, it is treated as drug-resistant TB. 

However, if the sample turns out to be intermediate/inconclusive, CB-NAAT is repeated using 2nd sample.

  • If the 2nd sample turns out to be positive for Rifampicin resistance, the patient is treated as Rifampicin resistant
  • If the 2nd sample turns out to be negative for Rifampicin resistance, the patient is treated as drug-sensitive
  • If the 2nd sample also turns out to be indeterminate, a fresh sample is taken for Line probe assay or liquid culture, to ascertain drug resistance.

A positive smear examination irrespective of CXR findings is diagnosed as microbiologically confirmed TB and started on ATT. Drug sensitivity is done for all new cases due to increasing resistance. Once these drug sensitivity results are available, treatment can be modified, if resistance is found.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G2P1 presents at 30 weeks of gestation with her USG scan, showing a single deepest vertical pocket of 10cm. On examination, her fundal height was greater than the period of gestation. The uterus felt tense, and there was difficulty palpating fetal parts. Fetal heart sounds were normal but auscultated with difficulty. Which among the following could be likely etiologies for this presentation?
  1. Red cell alloimmunization
  2. Maternal pre-eclampsia
  3. Posterior urethral valve
  4. Micrognathia
  5. Esophageal atresia
questions.solution:
An ultrasonography report showing a single vertical pocket of >8cm, with a fundal height greater than the period of gestation indicates polyhydramnios, causes of which may be red cell alloimmunization, micrognathia, and esophageal atresia. (1, 4, and 5)

Polyhydramnios or hydramnios refers to abnormally increased amniotic fluid volume. It is diagnosed when :

  • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) is greater than 24cm
  • The single deepest vertical pocket  (DVP) is greater than 8 cm
  • Amniotic fluid volume is greater than 2L

Other options: Maternal preeclampsia and posterior urethral valve are causes of oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed when AFI is less than 5 cm or a single deepest pocket of amniotic fluid is less than 2 cm.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has hearing difficulty in his right ear, with frequent episodes of tinnitus. Further clinical examination shows a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Given below is his brain MRI image. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI image are diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. The rollover phenomenon is seen in this condition.

When speech audiometry is done on this patient, it shows poor speech discrimination. A reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is called the rollover phenomenon. It is seen in retrocochlear type of hearing loss, as with an acoustic neuroma.

Vestibular schwannoma or ‘acoustic neuroma’ are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and arise from the vestibular division of the VIII nerve but rarely may arise from the cochlear division of the VIII nerve within the internal auditory canal.

  • Mostly seen in 40- 60 years and no sexual predilection.
  • Progressive unilateral hearing loss with tinnitus is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Vth cranial nerve is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved.
  • Other nerves involved are IX, X, and XI cranial nerves and may also cause displacement of the brainstem resulting in increased intracranial pressure.

MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Other options:

The recruitment phenomenon refers to abnormal growth of loud sounds (sound is amplified in order to be heard better). A loud sound that is tolerable by a normal ear may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in the recruiting ear and thus becomes intolerable. It is a feature of cochlear pathologies like Meniere's disease and presbycusis. 

Diplacusis is the discordance of sounds in which a single auditory stimulus of a particular frequency is heard at different pitches in both ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds produce vertigo due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

The recruitment phenomenon, diplacusis, and Tullio phenomenon are all seen in Meniere's disease.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presented to casualty with sudden onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, she was tachycardic, her blood pressure was normal, and there were no signs of shock. The uterus was tender and the fetal heart rate was markedly elevated. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of abdominal pain, maternal tachycardia, a tender uterus with vaginal bleeding, and fetal distress point to a diagnosis of abruptio placentae, for which primiparity is not a risk factor. The risk of developing abruption increases with increasing parity (primiparity is not a risk factor).

Abruptio placentae refer to the premature separation of the placenta, either partially or totally from its implantation site before delivery. It is initiated by hemorrhage into the decidua basalis. Consequently, a decidual hematoma forms and expands, causing the placenta to get separated and compressed.

The bleeding between the membranes and uterus escapes through the cervix leading to external hemorrhage. Less often, the blood gets retained between the detached placenta and the uterus, leading to concealed hemorrhage.

Risk factors for placental abruption:

  • Prior abruption
  • Increased age and parity 
  • Cocaine use, Cigarette smoking (Option A)
  • Preterm prematurely ruptured membrane (Option B)
  • Preeclampsia and chronic hypertension (Option D)
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Low birth weight
  • Hydramnios
  • Trauma
  • Uterine leiomyoma - especially if located near the mucosal surface behind the placental implantation site
  • Single umbilical artery

Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the triangle of pain?

choices.text: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.solution:
The ilioinguinal nerve is not a content of the triangle of pain.

The triangle of pain (Electrical hazard zone) is an anatomical landmark encountered during laparoscopic hernia repair surgery. Any damage to the contents of this structure can lead to chronic pain following hernia repair.

It is bounded by:

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

The ilioinguinal nerve is a branch of the L1 nerve root. It enters the abdominal wall by piercing the transversus abdominis muscle on the posterior aspect. It enters the inguinal canal as it goes inferomedially. It supplies the anterior surface of the scrotum or labia majora. It can be injured during open hernia repair.

questions.text: Artery which doesn’t contribute to formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus is
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis formed in Little’s area. It is situated in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, just above the nasal vestibule. It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults.

The arteries contributing to it are:

    • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
    • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
    • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery which supplies the nasal septum but doesn’t contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient with breathlessness, and dry cough on and off for the past 6 months. She provides a history of working in the sand filtration segment in a brick production unit for the last 15 years. An X-ray was done and is given below. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for the X-ray finding?
questions.solution:
The x-ray image shows eggshell calcification, Asbestosis is not a differential diagnosis for eggshell calcification.

There are no pathognomonic radiological features specific to asbestosis. Chest radiographs may show irregular opacities with a fine reticular pattern. Additional evidence of asbestos exposure such as calcified or noncalcified pleural plaques may be evident.

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Post-irradiation lymphoma
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Tuberculosis

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with bilateral conductive deafness, bloody nasal discharge, and hemoptysis. Chest radiography shows multiple and bilateral cavities. Serum creatinine is 3 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings point to a diagnosis of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Wegener's granulomatosis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis of small vessels with the formation of granulomas at multiple sites. The classic feature of this disease is the involvement of the triad of upper and lower respiratory tracts, and the kidneys.

Patients present with paranasal sinus pain and discharge (purulent or bloody) and may end up developing nasal septal perforation and saddle nose deformity. Eustachian tube block can lead to otitis media with effusion and conductive hearing loss. Lower respiratory tract involvement presents as cough and hemoptysis due to multiple, bilateral cavitary infiltrates in the lungs. Renal pathology typically evolves quickly into rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. It is important to note that there is no granuloma formation in the kidney and there is no immune complex deposition either.

Laboratory findings show elevated levels of c-ANCA (antiproteinase-3 ANCA), ESR, CRP, and RA factor. The diagnosis can be established by demonstration of necrotizing granulomatous inflammation on tissue biopsy in a suspected patient. The presence of ANCA antibodies is adjunct as they may be absent in some patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis now presents with weakness and loss of the bulk of thenar muscles and was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following structure is spared in this condition?
questions.solution:
Radial nerve is spared in carpal tunnel syndrome as it is not a content of carpal tunnel. 

10 structures pass through the carpal tunnel, most of which are flexor tendons (not the muscles themselves).

Carpal tunnel contents (10 structures): Also can be taken as 4 structures only if FDP and FDS are counted as 2 structures. 

  • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP-4 tendons).
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS-4 tendons).
  • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL-1 tendon).
  • Median nerve between tendons of FDP and FDS.

Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs due to the entrapment or compression of the median nerve as it traverses underneath the carpal tunnel to enter into the wrist. Patients usually present with pain associated with tingling and numbness involving the thumb, index and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger. The little finger is usually spared as it is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Tinel's sign and Phalen's test are seen on examining patients with carpal tunnel syndrome. A late sign of carpal tunnel syndrome is thenar atrophy as seen in this patient. 

Some conditions associated with carpal tunnel syndrome include the third trimester of pregnancy, people with repetitive trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, and cysts from the carpal joints. 

Management involves measures to remove any repetitive insults that cause symptoms, wrist splinting, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, steroid injection, etc. Surgical decompression is usually indicated in patients that do not improve.

Note: Ulnar nerve passes superficial to carpal tunnel

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman with no prior surgeries presents with recurrent bouts of dizziness, sweating, and weakness when she is fasting. FBS was found to be 40 mg/dL. Despite fasting, the insulin and C-peptide levels were found to be elevated. Which of the following is the likely cause?

FBS: fasting blood sugar
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness, sweating, and weakness) that occur when the patient is fasting, along with elevated insulin and C-peptide levels despite low FBS, point to a diagnosis of insulinoma. 

Insulinoma is the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET). It also has the least malignant potential out of all the PNETs. Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma:

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after administration of glucose

The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the measurement of blood glucose and serum insulin levels after a 72-hour fasting period. Along with elevated insulin levels, elevated C-peptide levels indicate that endogenous insulin in the patient's body is high, thus ruling out exogenous insulin administration (option A). After the fasting test is positive, CT or MRI is done to visualize the tumor. If the tumor is not seen in these investigations, an endoscopic ultrasound is used to make the definitive diagnosis. MEN1 syndrome should be considered in a young patient with insulinoma. 

Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. All patients planned for surgery are treated with diazoxide, which suppresses insulin secretion by keeping the K+ channels open. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas. For patients with multifocal tumors associated with MEN1 syndrome, the tumors on the right side of the portal vein are enucleated, and distal pancreatectomy is done because other non-functioning NETs may be present in the tail. 

Other options:

Dumping syndrome (option D), which occurs following gastrointestinal surgery, includes early and late dumping. Late dumping presents with features of hypoglycemia due to a sudden rise in blood glucose levels due to absorption from the small bowel. This patient has no prior history of surgeries. Furthermore, the persistence of high insulin levels despite fasting and low blood glucose level rule out this option.

Diabetes mellitus with insulin resistance (option C) will present with high FBS values due to the failure of insulin to act on the target organs. It will never present with hypoglycemia, unless a known diabetic is on hypoglycemic drugs (such as sulfonylureas, exogenous insulin) and there is a mismatch in the required dose and the dose that is taken.

questions.text: Flagellate dermatitis is caused by _____.
questions.solution:
Flagellate dermatitis is caused by bleomycin.

Flagellate erythema/ dermatitis is characterized by multiple red, macular streaks of erythema on the trunk and limbs. The streaks are aligned in a criss‐cross pattern, giving a whip-like or flagellate appearance. They may be sore or pruritic. 

Flagellate erythema is seen in

  • A side effect of bleomycin chemotherapy
  • The toxic effect after consumption of shitake mushrooms
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Adult-onset Still’s disease
  • Docetaxel therapy

It is self-limiting and usually resolves within a few days to weeks. Topical steroids and oral antihistamines can be given to relieve the associated pruritis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the OPD with complaints of fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. He recently also developed severe pain in his right knee. A malabsorption syndrome is suspected and a biopsy is taken which shows the following picture. A disturbance in which phase of nutrient absorption is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing foul-smelling diarrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and histopathology showing dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria and macrophages containing periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules is suggestive of Whipple disease where there is a disturbance in the lymphatic transport of absorbed lipids.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by the gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It presents as diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, arthralgia, and central nervous system & cardiac problems. The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Steatorrhea is characterized by excessive fecal fat and bulky, frothy, greasy, yellow, or clay-colored stools. Chronic malabsorptive disorders commonly occur due to pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, and Crohn's disease. In Whipple disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport. In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic obstruction.

Malabsorption occurs due to disturbance in at least one of the four phases of nutrient absorption:

  • Intraluminal digestion: In this phase, the proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into suitable forms for absorption. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include chronic pancreatitis and cystic fibrosis.
  • Terminal digestion: This phase involves hydrolysis of carbohydrates and peptides by the enzymes in the brush border of the small intestinal mucosa. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Transepithelial transport: In this phase nutrients, fluid, and electrolytes are transported across the small intestinal epithelium, and are processed within the epithelium as they pass. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, and inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Lymphatic transport: The absorbed lipids are transported. Abnormality in this phase is seen in Whipple disease.

questions.text: The abnormality noted in the given image of placenta is

choices.text: The cord is attached to the membranes
Fetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery
A small lobe of placenta lies seperate from main part

questions.solution:
The image depicts the battledore placenta in which the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.

In the Battledore placenta, the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a Previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

Other options:

Option A: Velamentous placenta - the cord is attached to the membranes and blood vessels pass through the membrane and then the placenta to supply it.

Option B: Circumvallate placenta - the fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery which is made of a double fold of amnion and chorion.

Option D: Succenturiate placenta - one or small lobes of the placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of bleeding gums and pain in the lower limbs. On examination, there were nodules present as seen in the image given below. The nodules were tender on palpation. What is the management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a history of bleeding gums and painful limbs with the image showing a scorbutic rosary is suggestive of Scurvy. The treatment of scurvy is the administration of vitamin C 100-200mg/day for 12 weeks.

Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary. 

Scurvy results from a deficiency of vitamin C. Vitamin C is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, a deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Hemorrhagic manifestations include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and perifollicular hemorrhages. Cutaneous manifestations include phrynoderma, corkscrew hairs -fractured and coiled hairs due to impaired keratin cross‐links by disulfide bonds, perifollicular hemorrhage, purpura, lower limb edema, and splinter hemorrhages

Scurvy is treated with vitamin C supplements of 100-200 mg/day orally or parenterally. The clinical improvement is seen within 1 week. The treatment should be continued for up to 3 months for complete recovery

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OP with painful genital ulcers. Gram staining revealed gram-negative coccobacilli as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a suitable culture medium?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painful genital ulcer with gram-negative coccobacilli arranged in parallel chains is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the suitable culture medium of Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid or soft sore is a venereal disease characterized by tender non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia. This infection remains localized, spreading only to the regional lymph nodes which are enlarged and painful. The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'rail road track' appearance.

On chocolate agar, enriched with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum, and containing vancomycin as a selective agent, H.ducreyi forms small, grey translucent colonies after incubation at 35°C under 10% CO and 2 high humidity in 2-8 days.

H.ducreyi requires X factor, but not V factor for growth. H.influenzae requires X and V factor for growth.

Note: Fish in-stream appearance is seen in Vibrio cholera.

questions.text: During the blood sample collection in a diabetic patient, gray top tubes are used for plasma glucose estimation because fluoride is an inhibitor of which of the following glycolytic enzymes?
questions.solution:
During the blood sample collection for plasma glucose estimation in a diabetic patient, gray top tubes are used for plasma glucose estimation because it contains sodium fluoride and fluoride is an inhibitor of enolase.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with abdominal pain and hematemesis after a bout of binge drinking. On endoscopy, a longitudinal mucosal tear is found in the gastroesophageal junction. Identify the correct statement about the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Conservative management is done in majority
Left gastroduodenal artery is the most common vessel to bleed

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mallory-Weiss syndrome. It is a self-limited condition and conservative management is done in the majority of the cases.

In Mallory–Weiss syndrome, vigorous vomiting produces a vertical split in the gastric mucosa, immediately below the squamocolumnar junction at the cardia in most cases. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting or retching. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The diagnosis can be easily confirmed by upper GI endoscopy. Management of Mallory-Weiss syndrome is usually conservative. When the endoscopy is being done for the diagnosis, injection epinephrine can be injected or clips can be used to stop the bleeding if the bleeding is too severe or if the patient has had severe blood loss.

Boerhaave syndrome is characterized by a tear in the lower third of the esophagus. This occurs when a patient vomits against a closed glottis, causing a leak into the surrounding structures such as the mediastinum, pleural cavity, and the peritoneum. Clinical features are described by the Mackler's triad, which includes vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. Boerhaave syndrome is essentially a type of esophageal perforation and should be managed as such. If the diagnosis is made early, endoscopic sealing of the perforation may be possible. If the diagnosis is delayed, or if there is concomitant mediastinitis, or if the pleura is also involved, then surgical intervention is indicated.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of easy fatiguability. Her blood examination showed mild anemia with target cells. Hemoglobin electrophoresis showed HbA2 levels of 6% with normal HbF and the Mentzer index was 6. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is β Thalassemia minor.

The presence of mild anemia, peripheral smear showing target cells with 6% HbA2, and normal HbF, with a Mentzer index of 6 indicate that this is a case of thalassemia minor.

β Thalassemia minor is a clinical syndrome caused due to heterozygous expression of one normal (β) gene and one abnormal β-thalassemia(β0/+) gene. It can either be present as β+/β or as β0/β. This occurs due to point mutations of the β thalassemia gene on chromosome 11. The predominant mechanisms are:

  • Splicing mutations are the most common cause of β+ thalassemia
  • Promoter region mutations are associated with β+ thalassemia
  • Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause of β0 thalassemia.

These mutations cause a diminished synthesis of β globin chains leading to anemia by decreased synthesis of normal HbA (α2β2) and decreased survival of red cells and their precursors due to imbalance in α and β globin synthesis and elevated γ and δ chain synthesis leading to increased HbF and HbA2 respectively.

β Thalassemia minor is more common clinically than other forms. These patients are usually asymptomatic or present with symptoms of mild anemia. Peripheral blood smear typically shows hypochromic, microcytic red cells with basophilic stippling, and target cells as shown in the image.

Diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis that reveals typical raised levels of HbA2 (α2δ2) ranging between 4-8% with normal HbF (α2γ2) levels. The Mentzer index of <12 is seen in thalassemia minor syndrome.

Thalassemia minor seldom requires treatment and if indicated is usually in patients after surgery, following childbirth, or to manage complications. Blood transfusions are the preferred modality of treatment.

β Thalassemia major (option C) is a clinical syndrome caused due to homozygous expression of abnormal abnormal β-thalassemia genes in the form of β+/β+, β+/β0, or β0/β0. The etiology is similar as described above. There is the complete absence or only minimal synthesis of the β globin chain. The predominant type of hemoglobin is HbF with very low HbA and normal to mildly increased HbA2.

Blood smears show severe red cell abnormalities, including marked anisocytosis and poikilocytosis, microcytosis, and hypochromia. Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. The reticulocyte count is elevated. A radiographic image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance.

The patients usually present with severe transfusion-dependent anemia and do not survive without them. Extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged and distorted bony prominences over the face leading to the characteristic 'chipmunk facies.'

β-thalassemia intermedia is a third genetically heterogeneous β-thalassemia variant of moderate severity. This category includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β+/β0-thalassemia. The Mentzer index is 12-14 in thalassemia intermedia.

Other options:

Option A - Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of microcytic anemia. It is characterized by the presence of microcytic hypochromic red cells with pencil cells. It can be differentiated from β Thalassemia minor by examining the blood smear and serum levels of iron, total iron-binding capacity, and serum ferritin. A definitive differentiation can be made in the favour of iron deficiency anemia when the Mentzer index is >14. 

Option B - α Thalassemia trait is caused by the deletion of two α-globin genes from a single chromosome (α/α,−/−) or the deletion of one α-globin gene from each of the two chromosomes (α/−, α/−). Patients present with symptoms similar to β thalassemia minor but there are normal or low HbA2 levels.

Note:

Mentzer index is defined as mean corpuscular volume per red cell count, i.e. MCV/RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron deficiency anemia and thalassemia trait as follows:

  • >14: Iron deficiency anemia
  • 12-14: Intermediate
  • <12 Thalassemia trait 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A Physiologist conducts an experiment on the comparison of pressure-volume curves for air-filled and saline-filled lungs. He then plots the graph of lung volume(on the y-axis ) against alveolar pressure(on the x-axis). Which of the following explains the changes seen in Graph A compared to Graph B?
questions.solution:
Graph A represents the plot obtained with a Saline/liquid-ventilated lung, as it shows much less hysteresis compared to a gas-ventilated lung. The absence of hysteresis can be explained by Laplace law.

The difference between the inflation and the deflation paths is called hysteresis. 

Laplace law

  • This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius.
  • P= 2T/R

In spherical structures like an alveolus, the distending pressure (P) equals two times the tension (T) divided by the radius (r). if tension is not reduced when the radius is reduced, the tension overcomes the distending pressure and the alveoli collapse resulting in decreased hysteresis.

  • When the lungs are filled with air, there is an interface between the alveolar fluid and the air in the alveoli; so, there is surface tension.
  • But, in the case of the saline solution-filled lungs, there is no air–fluid interface and there is no surface tension, making it more compliant.

Other options

Option A: The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically by Poiseullie's law.

where F = flow

PA − PB = pressure difference between two ends of the tube

η = viscosity
r = radius of the tube
L = length of the tube

Option B: Frank Starling's law stated that the force of contraction is proportional to the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber. 

Option D: Bell Magendie law states that the anterior or ventral roots of the spinal nerves are motor and the posterior or dorsal nerve roots are sensory.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female patient presents with petechiae and one episode of epistaxis. She gives a history of an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. Her lab reports are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000 cells/μL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing petechiae and one episode of epistaxis following upper respiratory tract infection, and lab reports showing a platelet count of 12,000/μL are suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Since this patient has had only one episode of epistaxis and her hemoglobin is normal, the most appropriate management for this patient would be prednisolone.

In patients without significant bleeding and without severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 5000 cells/μL), the initial treatment is with glucocorticoids such as prednisolone or dexamethasone.

If the patient has severe bleeding or severe thrombocytopenia, IVIg and glucocorticoids are used in conjunction. Anti-D is used as an alternative to IVIg, but is not preferred because of the risk of severe hemolytic reactions. Platelet transfusions (option B) are reserved for patients in whom there is a need to immediately raise the platelet counts. 

The decision to start treatment in a patient who is incidentally diagnosed and doesn't have any bleeding manifestations is based on the platelet count. Treatment is usually started for these patients if the platelet count is < 30,000 cells/μL.

Splenectomy (option C) has been used previously for patients who relapse after glucocorticoid therapy, but is now a reserved treatment option. In most adult patients, ITP resolves spontaneously, and so it is reasonable to observe the patient with intermittent treatment with IVIg before surgery is considered.

Other drugs which are used in the treatment of ITP include anti-CD20 antibody rituximab, and thrombopoietin (TPO) receptor agonists such as romiplostim and eltrombopag.  

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with low-grade fever. On examination, a characteristic slapped cheek appearance is seen on the face. Which of the following describes the genetic makeup of the pathogen?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A child presents with neonatal hypotonia, tachypnoea, abnormal eye movements, and mental retardation. On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a ‘batwing appearance’ as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the Molar tooth sign suggest the diagnosis of Joubert syndrome. The image shows an axial T2 weighted image at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles demonstrating the molar tooth sign.

Joubert syndrome:

These are a group of recessive congenital ataxia disorders in which typically there is

  • Neonatal hypotonia
  • Tachypnoea
  • Abnormal eye movements
  • Mental retardation associated with a particular pattern of cerebellar dysgenesis with a molar tooth-type malformation and vermis hypoplasia

MRI features :

  • The cardinal feature is the presence of a molar tooth sign which is created by a combination of
    • Midbrain hypoplasia with an
    • Abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa and
    • A failure of the superior cerebellar peduncles to decussate across the midline.
  • On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a batwing appearance
  • Cerebellar hypoplasia
  • Midline vermian cleft
  • Dysplastic small vermis
  • The midbrain is small

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 36 weeks gestation, presents with palpitations, protrusion of the eyeball, and heat intolerance. On blood investigations, it was found that she had increased T3 and T4 levels and decreased TSH levels.  Which of the following should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is thyrotoxicosis. As she is in her third trimester, the drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis is methimazole.

Treatment of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy has been summarized in the table below.

Thyrotoxicosis during pregnancy is usually controlled by thioamide drugs. Propylthiouracil was preferred previously because it partially inhibits the conversion of T4 to T3 and crosses the placenta less readily than methimazole. However, since it has a higher risk of causing propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy, methimazole is prescribed according to guidelines in the second trimester and third trimesters. Methimazole is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy. 

Other options:

Option B: Subtotal thyroidectomy is done once the hyperthyroidism is medically controlled. It is usually avoided during pregnancy, however, may be done in some cases in the second trimester where it can't be controlled via medication.

Option D: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it may cause fetal thyroid gland destruction.

questions.text: Identify the type of isomerism shown by the 2 molecules represented in the below image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows glucose and fructose that differ in the functional groups. Hence they are functional isomers.

Fructose has the same molecular formula as glucose but differs in that there is a keto group in position 2 whereas in glucose there is an aldehyde group in position 1.

Other options

Option A: Anomerism

Anomers are characterized by the difference in spatial configuration of —H and —OH groups with reference to the first carbon atom in aldoses and the second carbon atom in ketoses. D-glucose has two anomers, alpha and beta varieties.

Option C: Enantiomerism/ D and L isomerism

The orientation of the —H and —OH groups around the penultimate carbon atom determines whether the sugar belongs to the D- or L- series.

  • When the —OH group on the penultimate carbon atom of the sugar is on the right side, then the sugar is designated as a D- isomer/enantiomer.
  • When the –OH group is on the left, it is an L-isomer/enantiomer.
  • Naturally occurring monosaccharides- D-sugars
  • Naturally occurring amino acids –L-isomers

Option D: Isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with the exception of the carbonyl carbon) are defined as epimers of each other.

Examples of epimers of glucose:

  • Mannose (epimerized at carbon 2)
  • Galactose (epimerized at carbon 4)

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria and mild hepatomegaly. Suspecting amyloidosis, a renal biopsy was taken, which seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal amyloidosis in which the biopsy specimen shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light with congo-red staining.

Amyloidosis is a condition caused due to the deposition of abnormal fibrillar proteins in extracellular spaces. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Based on the involvement of organ systems it may be classified as systemic or localized. Hereditary amyloidosis is a separate group of heterogeneous disorders with many distinctive patterns of organ involvement. 

Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. 

On light microscopy (with hematoxylin and eosin stain): Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

Congo red stain, which is used to observe amyloid deposits is shown in the image below: 

  1. Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to amorphous extracellular material, as seen by the focal positive staining.
  2. Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.
 The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry.

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with this stain.


Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue. 


The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli Helicobacter pylori.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve:

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug B is more efficacious than drug A

questions.solution:
The more the curve is to the left, the more its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent on the given dose-response curve (DRC).

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater its potency.

Hence in the given DRC drug B is the most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy (Option B and D), and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious. (Option C)

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is screaming in pain while being wheeled into the labor room at 2 am. On examination, her cervix is well-effaced and is 4 cm dilated. What is the preferred anesthetic technique to ensure this patient has a painless labour?
questions.solution:
A lumbar epidural is the preferred anesthetic technique to ensure that this patient has painless labor.

For adequate pain relief, the sensory block of T10-L1 is required during the first stage of labor, and S2-S4 is required during the second stage. The epidural catheter placed at L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace sufficiently provides T10–S5 neural blockade.

Maternal hydration has to be ensured with normal saline or Hartmann's solution infusion before epidural blockade is commenced. The patient's heart rate, blood pressure, and fetal heart rate have to be monitored every 15 minutes following the induction of anesthesia, and maternal hypotension has to be treated promptly.  

Contraindications of epidural analgesia include neurological diseases, maternal coagulopathy or anticoagulant therapy, hypovolemia, supine hypotension, and skin infection at the injection site.

Complications of epidural analgesia include hypotension due to sympathetic blockade, post-spinal headache, pain at the injection site, and injury to nerves. 

Option A: Pudendal nerve block is given in the second stage of labor just before delivery of the baby to provide analgesia to the vulva and anus​. It is mostly used for forceps and vaginal breech deliveries. However, it has no effect on the pain of contractions. It is also given before repair of episiotomy or perineal lacerations.

Option B: Spinal anesthesia for labor analgesia has the advantage of a rapid and reliable onset of the neural blockade, and it is technically easier to administer compared to epidural analgesia. However, repeated intrathecal injections may be required for prolonged labor, thus increasing the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

Option C: Caudal epidural is largely avoided for pain relief in obstetrics. It requires large volumes of a local anesthetic to anesthetize upper lumbar and lower thoracic dermatomes to provide adequate labor analgesia. Though rare, accidental puncture of the fetus is a possibility.

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with neck nodes. Examination of left ear reveals a dull tympanic membrane, deafness and tinnitus. On tympanogram, a Type B curve is obtained. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

The given scenario of neck nodes (cervical lymphadenopathy) in a 70-year-old male (5th -7th decade) with unilateral serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane and Type B tympanogram) are all suggestive of a nasopharyngeal growth, probably carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking. It commonly occurs in males in the 5th to 7th decade. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex 
    • CN II - exophthalmos 
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Examination of the ear shows a dull tympanic membrane and audiometry shows a Type B curve due to the presence of fluid in the middle ear. The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult suggests nasopharyngeal growth.

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to the involvement of the CN X may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Other options:

Option A: Chronic suppurative otitis media presents with ear discharge and perforation will be seen on examination.

Option B: On otoscopy, a red reflex is seen through the intact tympanic membrane in the glomus tumor. Tumor arising from the floor of the middle ear gives a rising sun appearance.

Option D: The dull tympanic membrane on examination and Type B tympanogram suggest the presence of fluid in the middle ear as the cause for deafness and not sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A patient with CKD presents with normocytic normochromic anemia. Which of the following management strategies is appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Anemia due to CKD is treated with iron supplementation followed by darbepoetin.

Anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. It presents as normocytic normochromic anemia in the peripheral smear. Patients complain of fatigue and diminished ability to exercise. Anemic associated with CKD is treated with erythropoietin stimulating agents (ESAs) such as darbepoetin. However, adequate iron stores are required in the bone marrow before the treatment is initiated with ESA. This is because new red cell production once ESA is administered will exceed the amount of iron that is available in the body stores.

For CKD patients who are not yet on dialysis, oral iron supplementation should be done. For patients on hemodialysis, IV iron can be administered during the dialysis itself. Apart from iron, supplementation of vitamin B12 and folate should also be done. If the anemia fails to respond to ESA administration even with adequate iron stores, it can be due to inflammation (acute or chronic), infection, malignancy, severe hyperparathyroidism, or inadequate dialysis.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
The researcher may use attributable risk to express the increased incidence of asthma in the exposed children.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Other Options:

Option B: Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option C: Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Option D: Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome in case-control studies.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.

  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image given below.
questions.solution:
The above image with fish-like scales is suggestive of ichthyosis. It is a family of genetic disorders characterized by the presence of excessive amounts of dry thickened scaly skin.  

The commonest form of ichthyosis vulgaris is due to a genetic defect in the gene FLG coding for filaggrin protein. Ichthyosis usually develops during the first months of life. 

The patients present with light grey scales mainly on the extensor surfaces of the extremities and the trunk. The scaling may disappear or reduce in the summer and when there is increased humidity. They usually have accentuated palmar creases.

The condition is managed with ointments like glycerol-containing creams that hydrate the stratum corneum.

Other options:

Option A: Acrodermatitis enteropathica is caused by a defect in the absorption of zinc. It presents as eczematous plaques that are usually periorificial on the face or the anogenital area. They may become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with crusting at the edges. It is shown below.

 

Option C: Atopic dermatitis in children classically have patches and plaques on antecubital and popliteal fossae. Adults have chronic lichenified lesions mainly on the hands. It is associated with itching. It is shown below.

Option D: Kaposi sarcoma: Skin lesions of Kaposi sarcoma are dark blue to purple and may partially blanch when swollen. They are usually multifocal and may fuse to form plaques and tumors. It is seen below.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome?

1. Arborizing pattern of connective tissue
2. Mutation in the STK11 gene
3. Multiple hamartomatous polyps
4. Autosomal recessive
5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are 1, 2, and 3.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The pigmentation is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years.

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11 are present in half the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histologic examination shows a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

A complication of Peutz-Jeghers polyps is intussusception, which is occasionally fatal. Peutz-Jegher syndrome is associated with a markedly increased risk of colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Note:- Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen in FAP, not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: The following image shows a multi-parameter monitor with normal pulse waveforms. Which of the following phenomenons is responsible for the finding marked in yellow arrows in the waveforms?
questions.solution:
The finding marked with yellow coloured arrows in the pulse waveforms is indicative of the dicrotic notch. Dicrotic notch is caused by the closing of the aortic valve.

The dicrotic notch, a small oscillation in the falling phase of the pulse wave caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve snaps shuts.

questions.text: A known hypertensive presented with intermittent loin pain. His brother passed away two years ago due to a ruptured berry aneurysm. CT abdomen done is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Caused by mutations in chromosomes 16 and 4
Can progress to end-stage renal disease

questions.solution:
The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The predominant feature in patients with ADPKD is hypertension, not hypotension.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4) (option B). The patients present with hypertension and flank pain. The cause of the pain is the infection of the renal cysts, hemorrhage or concomitant stone formation. Gross hematuria can also occur when the cyst ruptures. The most important causes of mortality in patients with ADPKD are cardiovascular complications due to hypertension, and infections of the cyst. The patients progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by late middle age (option D). 

Manifestations of ADPKD in other organs include:

  • Cysts in liver, pancreas, spleen, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Mitral valve prolapse (option C)
  • Colonic diverticulae 
  • Abdominal wall hernias

The diagnosis is made using typical clinical features, family history consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance, and the presence of multiple, bilateral cysts on imaging. Ultrasound is often used as the first-line investigation. CT and T2 weighted MRI are more sensitive than ultrasound in detecting smaller-sized cysts.

Treatment includes strict control of BP using blockers of RAAS, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers. Tolvaptan (vasopressin antagonist), sirolimus, and everolimus (mTOR pathway inhibitors) have been shown to delay the progression of renal disease. More than half of the patients with ADPKD eventually require renal replacement therapy in the form of hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or renal transplant.

questions.text: A patient presented with a classical finding of pulsus parvus et tardus. Which of the following pressure-volume loops will be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Pulsus parvus et tardus (i.e. a weak and late pulse) is classically associated with aortic stenosis. Amongst the given pressure-volume loops, the one that corresponds to aortic stenosis is A.  

In aortic stenosis, as there is high outflow resistance, the pressure gradient across the aortic valve is increased. The stroke volume is also severely decreased as the ventricles are not completely emptied.

The image given below shows pressure-volume loops in various valvular heart disorders.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

The volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. This results in a decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

The image given below shows a normal pressure-volume loop.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with AIDS presents to the local clinic complaining of fever, nausea, vomiting and confusion. A lumbar puncture is performed and the microscopic appearance of India ink-stained CSF specimen is given below. Which of the following drugs is most beneficial in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the India ink preparation demonstrating clear halos is suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this condition.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon feces, causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. It causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised individuals, it disseminates to CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation, as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles. Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine has been considered the standard treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

Other options: 

Ketoconazole is usually used for chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Nystatin is also used for mucocutaneous forms of candidiasis.

Miconazole is used for topical fungal infections like oral thrush, and vaginitis.

questions.text: A female patient complains of palpitations and weight loss. Laboratory evaluation shows thyroid-receptor antibody. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Associated with enlargement of extraocular muscles

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Graves' disease. Radionuclide scan shows increased uptake with diffuse distribution in Graves' disease.

The hyperthyroidism of Graves’ disease is due to the presence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI). These are synthesized by lymphocytes present in the thyroid gland, as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes. TSI include TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb), which act on the TSH receptors and stimulate the thyroid gland to produce and release more thyroid hormones, T3 and T4. Feedback inhibition by thyroid hormones causes TSH levels to be suppressed (option D).

Patients present with features of hyperthyroidism like hyperactivity, irritability, heat intolerance, sweating, and palpitations. Diarrhea, weight loss despite increased appetite, and oligomenorrhea are also seen. On examination, tremors and proximal muscle weakness might be seen. Pretibial myxedema (option A) refers to the noninflamed indurated plaque, pink-purple in color, which is seen most commonly on the skin of the anterior aspect of the leg. Thyroid acropachy is a form of clubbing of the fingers. Both these features are relatively specific to Graves' disease but are not seen in all the patients.

Graves ophthalmopathy occurs due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles (option B) due to marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space, accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate, and increased numbers of adipocytes. Early signs of Graves' ophthalmopathy include lid retraction and lid lag on downgaze. Later, the patients develop proptosis, diplopia, corneal damage (due to proptosis), and optic nerve compression causing permanent vision loss. 

The diagnosis of Graves' disease is established by measuring TSH levels (will be suppressed) and T3/T4 levels (will be elevated). Measurement of TRAb is required if the diagnosis is unclear. Radionuclide scan shows diffusely increased uptake in cases of Graves' disease. 

Treatment of Graves' disease includes:

  • Anti-thyroid drugs such as propylthiouracil, carbimazole, and methimazole. Propylthiouracil is the preferred anti-thyroid drug during pregnancy especially till 14-16 weeks, because carbimazole and methimazole are associated with aplasia cutis (absence of skin, usually on the scalp). 
  • Propranolol is given to control adrenergic effects before the effect of anti-thyroid drugs takes effect fully.
  • Radioiodine ablation can be used as a first-line modality, or can be used for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs. Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications for radioiodine ablation. 
  • Total thyroidectomy is done for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs and prefer surgical treatment over radioiodine ablation.

In smears stained with Giemsa or methylene blue, the following organisms show bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear.

  • Yersinia pestis
