questions.text: A pregnant woman is bitten by the following insect and develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. There is no history of contact with infected animal hide or skin. A positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins is observed. What will be the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins, and the life cycle of a trombiculid mite (which acts as the vector) are suggestive of scrub typhus. Humans are seen to be infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae (chiggers). The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients the DOC is doxycycline.

Azithromycin or rifampin is administered as an alternative for patients allergic to doxycycline and in pregnancy. An alternative in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is chloramphenicol.

Scrub Typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus which is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Cutaneous anthrax also presents with a characteristic black eschar, which is caused by Bacillus anthracis. It is commonly seen in tanners or hide porters who come in contact with infected animal hide and skins.

 

Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of Scrub Typhus in adults. Doxycycline is a tetracycline that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Tetracyclines are active against MRSA and MSSA. Doxycycline and minocycline can be used in cutaneous MRSA infections. Ricketssia and chlamydia are highly susceptible to tetracyclines. Tetracyclines are considered fist line agents for chlamydial infections like non-specific urethritis/ endocervicitis and rickettsial infections like typhus, rocky mountain spotted fever, Q fever. They are also second-line drugs in syphilis patients who are allergic to penicillin.

Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic drug with more active against gram-positive  than gram-negative. They are  effective against spirochetes, Haemophilus ducreyi, Vibrio cholera, Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Other uses of doxycycline:

  • Doxycycline as an alternative to penicillin for the treatment of leptospirosis.
  • Doxycycline treatment for 21 days is the first-line therapy for lymphogranuloma venerum. 
  • Doxycycline is indicated as one of the first-line treatment for borreliosis.

  • Doxycycline can be taken as prophylaxis before going to malaria-endemic places.

    Chemoprophylaxis in travelers:

    • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day can be started 2 days before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel.
    • If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week can be started 2 weeks before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel.

Doxycycline does not require dose reduction in renal failure.

Doxycycline and tetracycline are not preferred in pregnant women/children due to their effect on teeth and bones especially in children < 8years.

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic.

Azithromycin has a high volume of distribution. The tissue concentrations exceed serum concentrations by 10- to 100-fold. It is slowly released from tissue stores to produce an elimination half life approaching 3 days.

The unique property of azithromycin makes it appropriate for once daily dosing and shortening dosage period. A single 1 g azithromycin is as effective as 7 day course of doxycycline for chlamydial cervicitis and urethritis. Azithromycin is also safe for use in young children and pregnant women.

Other uses of Azithromycin:

  • Recommended therapy for severe babesiosis is azithromycin plus atovaquone.
  • Triple drug therapy for Mycobacterium avium complex regimen includes a Rifamycin, like rifampicin, Ethambutol and a Macrolide, like clarithromycin or azithromycin
  • Azithromycin 2g single dose is an alternative that can cover both Gonococcal and Non-gonococcal cervicitis . Three organisms needed to be covered when it comes to cervicitis in women
  • Gonorrhoea
    • Recommended regimen : Ceftriaxone 250mg IM + Azithromycin 1g oral single dose.
    • Alternative regimen: Cefixime 400 mg orally in a single dose + Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose
  • Chlamydia
    • Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7 days (or) Azithromycin 1g single dose
  • Mycoplasma
    • Azithromycin 1g single dose.

Azithromycin 2g single dose is an alternative that can cover all the given strains.

Note

  • Usually a combination of Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin is used as Azithromycin alone is lot inferior in treating gonococcus.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.

questions.text:
A mother brings her 5-year-old daughter for evaluation. Physical examination reveals breast development, axillary hair, pubic hair, and axillary odor. Laboratory studies show elevated GnRH, LH, and FSH. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

GnRH - Gonadotropin-releasing hormone
LH - Luteinizing hormone
FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a girl child with breast development (thelarche) and axillary/ pubic hair development (adrenarche) before 8 years of age with elevated GnRH, LH, and FSH levels is suggestive of central precocious puberty.

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years. Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 9 years. Central/ GnRH-dependent precocious puberty occurs due to the premature activation of the intact hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Increased levels of GnRH are present which lead to increased levels of LH and FSH. The cause may be idiopathic or central nervous system disorders such as hypothalamic hamartomas and other CNS tumors, tubercular meningitis, and head trauma.

Option B: Peripheral/ GnRH-independent or pseudo precocious puberty: This occurs due to the stimulation of sex steroids independent of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. They have high levels of estradiol (females) or testosterone (males) associated with suppressed LH and FSH. The causes include ovarian tumors, adrenal hyperplasia/neoplasm, hypothyroidism, hepatoblastoma, and iatrogenic-estrogen administration.

Option C: Incomplete precocious puberty may be in the form of premature thelarche, premature adrenarche, or premature menarche occurring in isolation. Since the given case has premature breast development (thelarche) as well as premature axillary/ pubic hair development (adrenarche), it is not a case of incomplete precocious puberty. 

Option D: Precocious puberty with secondary sexual characteristics of the patient's own gender is termed isosexual, and that with secondary sexual characteristics of the opposite gender is termed contrasexual. Contrasexual precocious puberty presents as feminization in males and virilization in females (the given case has isosexual characteristics).

questions.text: A young frequent traveler presented with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms were gradually worsening over the past 2 weeks. A widely used tube agglutination test was ordered for this patient. Which of the following statements is true regarding this test?

choices.text: High titre value in a single  test is confirmative
Increase in titre after one week indicates anamnestic response
Agglutination titre depends on the stage of the disease
Early antibiotic treatment shows good agglutination response

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of typhoid fever and the widely used tube agglutination test is the Widal test. In this test, the agglutination titer depends on the stage of the disease. 

Enteric fever (Typhoid fever) caused by Salmonella species. The patient presents with stepladder pyrexia, abdominal symptoms, headache, and malaise.

Widal Test: This is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's sera. The antigens used in Widal's test include:
  • O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
  • H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Paratyphoid O antigens cross-reacts with the typhoid O antigen due to the sharing of factor 12, hence O antibody cannot differentiate between the Salmonella types.

Interpretation: 

  • The agglutination titer will depend on the stage of the disease:
    • Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week. 
    • The titer increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines gradually.
  • The H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.
    • H antibodies appear earliest after infection and persist for several months.
    • The O antibodies follow the appearance of H antibodies and disappear in a few weeks. 
  • The 4-fold rise in titers between 1st and 3rd week is highly significant as compared to a single high titer (Option A):
    • This is because, in persons who had a prior enteric fever, there is a transient rise of titer due to unrelated infections (malaria, dengue), known as an anamnestic reaction.
    • Therefore, after a one-week interval, if the titer increases, it indicates true infection. If the titer decreases, it indicates an anamnestic reaction. (Option B)
  • Cases treated early with antibiotics may show poor agglutinin response. (Option D)

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with a black-colored nodule on his face as shown. There was no prior nevus in the area. The nodule has progressively increased in size over the last 1 week. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a nodular variant of melanoma. It is more aggressive than other variants.

Nodular melanoma accounts for 15% of all melanoma cases. The lesions arise de novo in the skin and are more frequently seen in males. They appear as black or blue papular lesions. They lack a horizontal growth phase but have a prominent vertical growth phase. This is why they tend to be sharply demarcated and more aggressive. Lesions can also be amelanotic.

Other important variants of melanoma include:

Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common variant of melanoma. It usually arises from a pre-existing nevus after a long period of slow change in the morphology of the lesion. There is rapid growth in few months prior to the presentation. These lesions tend to develop a vertical growth phase later, which manifests clinically as nodularity in the lesion. Superficial spreading melanoma is shown in the image below:

 

Lentigo maligna melanoma (Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle) is a variant of malignant melanoma that occurs due to cumulative exposure to UV radiation, while the other variants occur due to short-lasting but intense exposure, such as holiday tans. It presents as a variegated brown macule (as shown below) on the face, neck, and hands. The patients are usually elderly females. The lesion progresses slowly and has less metastatic potential than other variants.

 

Acral lentiginous melanoma is more commonly seen in dark-skinned patients. It affects the skin of palms and soles. It presents as an irregular macule as shown below.

 

Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clue towards the diagnosis of subungual melanoma. It is characterized by pigmentation of the proximal nail fold, that widens progressively to produce a pigmented macule and nail dystrophy.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text: A senior pediatric resident uses Silverman Anderson scoring system to assess respiratory distress in newborns. Which of the following components is given a score of 1?

choices.text: Upper chest movement showing inspiratory lag

questions.solution:
According to Silverman Anderson's score, upper chest movement showing inspiratory lag is given a score of 1. 

Expiratory grunting that is audible without a stethoscope and markedly visible xiphoid retractions are given a score of 2. An absence of nasal flaring would be given a score of 0.

Silverman Anderson's score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates. Components of this scoring system include:

    Score    0      1       2

1. Upper chest retraction

(Chest movement)

 Synchronized Lag on inspiration See-saw

2. Lower chest retraction

(Intercostal retraction)

 None Just visible Marked
3. Xiphoid    retraction None Just visible Marked
4. Nasal flaring None Minimal Marked
5. Grunt Not audible Audible with Stethoscope Audible with naked ear

 

The Silverman Anderson Retraction Score is more suited for preterms, however, the Downes’ Score can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Components of Downes' score are respiratory rate, cyanosis, air entry, grunt, and retractions.

questions.text: A male patient who lost his job recently became irritable and had a sad mood for most of the time. Thinking about the future made him worried and he felt irritated towards his family members. He occasionally went out for watching movies with his friends and was able to enjoy but on returning home he felt similar symptoms. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sad and irritable mood following a loss of job recently and impairment in the social functioning point to a probable diagnosis of adjustment disorder. 

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event. Stressors may be:

  • Single like loss of job or divorce 
  • Multiple like the death of a parent together with the loss of a job 
  • Recurrent like seasonal business difficulties

Diagnosing criteria for adjustment disorder include:

  • Development of emotional or behavioral response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor
  • The symptoms or behavior are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met - 
    • The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor
    • Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning
  • Stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder
  • The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement
  • Once the stressor is terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than an additional 6 months

Treatment:

  • Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice
  • Pharmacotherapy- anxiolytic or antidepressant medications 

Others options: 

Option A: Generalized anxiety disorder is excessive worry and anxiety with respect to several activities or events for most days during at least 6 months period. 

Option C: Mixed anxiety with depression is diagnosed when there are subsyndromal symptoms of both anxiety and depression along with autonomic symptoms such as tremors, palpitation, dry mouth, and sensation of churning in the stomach. 

Option D: Atypical depression is a type of depression characterized by mood reactivity, which is brightening of the mood in response to positive events, significant weight gain or increase in appetite; hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity, resulting in sig­nificant social or occupational impairment.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with complaints of dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. A diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence was suspected. All the following tests can help in the diagnosis of this condition, except _____.
questions.solution:
All the above tests can help in the diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence, except the methylene blue 3 swab test. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done for genitourinary fistulae.

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction. It is generally due to hypermobility of the urethra, loss of posterior angle, or sphincteric dysfunction. The risk factors include older age, post-menopausal status, multiparity, obesity, smoking,  pregnancy and puerperium, and hereditary conditions which lead to loss of collagen tissue.

Tests done for GSI (Genuine stress incontinence) are:

  • Stress test (Option A): The patient is catheterized after she voids urine and the residual urine in the bladder is measured. Examining for objective evidence of a leak:
    • The patient is asked to squat over a preweighed absorbent pad and is asked to cough and strain.
    • The patient is placed in a lithotomy position and asked to cough and strain for further evidence of a leak.
  • Cotton swab stick test (Option B): A Q tip cotton swab is introduced into the urethra. Initially, the tip of the swab would be horizontal to the floor. Upon straining, in patients without GSI, the tip of the swab would not shift more than 10-15 degrees above the horizontal. In patients with GSI, the tip might go beyond 50-70 degrees from the horizontal.
  • Marshall and Bonney test (Option D): The region of the bladder neck is elevated. If there is no leakage of urine on straining, it indicates a favorable outcome following surgical repair.
  • Urethroscopy.
  • Urodynamic evaluation- cystometry, urethrocystometry, uroflowmetry, etc.

Management includes : 

  • Conservative approach: Kegel pelvic floor exercises, magnetic/electric stimulation for nerve injuries, estrogen cream for post-menopausal women, etc
  • Surgical management: The various surgeries include:
    • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz and Pereyra Burch
    • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension
    • Slings
      • Tension-free sling
      • Transobturator type
    • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck

Methylene blue 3 swab test is used to diagnose genitourinary fistulae. Three cotton swabs are placed in the vagina—one at the vault, one in the middle, and one just above the introitus. The methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder through a rubber catheter and the patient is asked to walk for about 5 minutes. She is then asked to lie down and the swabs are inspected. If the swabs are stained with urine and not with the dye, it is indicative of a ureteric fistula. If the lowermost swab is stained blue, it is indicative of a urethral fistula. If the lower 2 swabs are stained blue, it is indicative of a vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: A factory worker presents to the dermatology OPD with the following lesions on his fingers which are painful and pruritic. He recently switched to a new brand of rubber gloves at work. He has had such lesions develop previously with the same brand. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing sago grain vesicles point towards a likely diagnosis of pompholyx.

Pompholyx is a form of eczema of the palms and soles in which edema fluid accumulates to form visible vesicles or bullae. It shows confluent vesicles that are painful and pruritic. It is also called vesicular eczema of palms and soles. This gives a sago grain or tapioca vesicle appearance.

Predisposing factors:

  • Atopy
  • Naturally dry skin
  • Allergic or irritant dermatitis - chromate, epoxy glues, and rubber
  • Filaggrin gene mutations are predisposing factors

Treatment:

  • First-line - Emollients, irritant, and allergen avoidance
  • Second-line - Topical corticosteroids
  • Third line:
    • Alitretinoin
    • PUVA
    • Azathioprine
    • Ciclosporin
    • Methotrexate

 

Other options:

Option A: Blistering distal dactylitis presents as multiple bullae with seropurulent fluid on the volar aspects of the hands and fingers usually in young children. Lesions appear over a few days and may leave superficial ero­sions secondary to usually streptococcal or staphylococcal infections.

Option B: Bullous impetigo presents as large bullae that progressively increase in size (1-2 cm in diameter) and do not rupture easily. Impetigo is a contagious superficial pyogenic infection of the skin. It is mainly caused by Staphylococcal infections and less commonly by Streptococcal infections. It is frequently seen in preschool and young age children.

Option D: Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction with itchy, erythematous papules and papulovesicles that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presents with complaints of passing reddish-brown colored urine for the past few months. She also complains of severe intermittent abdominal pain. Her lab reports reveal anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Flow cytometry shows CD55/CD59 negative RBCs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The flow cytogram shows a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (in the left lower quadrant), characteristic of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

In PNH, the blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity: 

  • Decay accelerating factor, or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

RBCs deficient in these GPI-linked proteins are susceptible to complement-mediated lysis resulting in intravascular hemolysis by the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex. During sleep, there is a slight decrease in pH, which increases the activity of the complement.

It is characterized by recurrent intravascular hemolysis that can also be associated with pancytopenia and venous thrombosis. Patients present with complaints of passing blood in urine or anemia. In the case of venous thrombosis, they can present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain.

Eculizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that has greatly improved the outcome for many patients with PNH from around the world. It works by inhibiting complement C5 which then prevents the activation of the complement cascade, thus preventing intra-vascular hemolysis. Supportive management of PNH includes folic acid and iron supplementation. Bone marrow transplantation is another option for the treatment of this condition.

Other options:

Option A: Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, their deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin. Clinical features include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stress. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

Option D: Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation of Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. Polycythemia shows a slight predominance in males. Most of the cases are incidental findings with high hemoglobin, hematocrit, or red cell count which are seen in other causes of erythrocytosis. Aquagenic pruritis is one of the most common symptoms associated with polycythemia vera. Digital ischemia, easy bruising, or gastrointestinal bleeding can occur due to thrombocytosis or vascular stasis. Treatment: Phlebotomy serves initially to reduce the hyperviscosity by reducing the red cell mass. Ruxolitinib, hydroxyurea, and pegylated interferon alpha are used for pruritis intractable to the antihistamine.

questions.text: What is the location of the target antigen in the condition represented in the immunofluorescence of skin sample shown below?
questions.solution:
Immunofluorescence pattern shown above is of fish-net appearance, which is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.

The location of target antigens in the given condition is intraepithelial.  This fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 > Dsg1), which are present inter-cellularly.

Direct immunofluorescence of skin sample with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis. The bullae (blisters) of pemphigus vulgaris occur from destruction within the epidermis; therefore, they are

  • Thin and fragile- rupture frequently
  • Painful (not pruritic)
  • Involves oral mucosa
  • Nikolsky’s sign positive: Slight rubbing of the skin results in peeling off of the epidermis. It is also seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

Other patterns seen on Direct Immunofluorescence in Vesiculobullous disorders are

  1. Linear Pattern (shore-line fluorescence pattern)
  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits along the DermoEpidermal Junctions (DEJ): Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ: Linear IgA dermatosis

2. Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis

questions.text: A boy was brought with complaints of pain over the left flank, associated with fever with chills with leukocytosis. The CT scan of the patient is given below.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with flank pain, fever, leucocytosis, and a CT scan showing a heterogenous, hypodense collection in the psoas muscle is suggestive of a psoas abscess.

Note that in the given axial section, the pus collection lies posteromedial to the kidneys and immediately lateral to the vertebral column, affecting the psoas major muscle. Hence a renal pathology (options A and D) is ruled out.

Psoas abscess is a type of retroperitoneal abscess. It occurs due to a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment due to an infection. Tuberculosis of the spine is the leading cause of psoas abscess in resource-limited countries. Because of the decline of M. tuberculosis as a major pathogen in resource-rich countries, psoas abscess in these places is mostly secondary to a contiguous spread of infection from the gastrointestinal or urinary tract. It can also be seen secondary to Crohn's disease.

Clinical features include back pain and fever. A soft, fluctuant swelling pointing towards the groin may be present, because of the tracking of the pus along the iliopsoas muscle. Pain on passive extension of the hip due to spasm of the psoas muscle may be present (positive psoas sign).

A CT scan helps in the diagnosis and delineating the possible source of the infection. It is treated with percutaneous CT-guided drainage under antibiotic cover. Surgical intervention may be required if these are unsuccessful.

The image given below shows the hypodense collection in the psoas muscle in a coronal CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, suggestive of psoas abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following Inhalational agent would you avoid in a patient with acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distension?
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distension is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has the potential to expand air containing cavities as it can diffuse into and accumulate in them. Hence it should be avoided in patients undergoing surgery for acute intestinal obstruction.

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: The method of asphyxia shown in the given image is ______
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of mugging where strangulation is caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow.

In this case, the pressure is put upon the neck by the arm held around the throat. The attack is usually made from behind, with the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow and pressure exerted when the front and sides of the larynx. 

A diffuse abrasion is seen along the margin of the jaw due to the friction of the forearm. Death can occur due to asphyxia or reflex cardiac arrest

Other options:

Option A: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened with the help of two sticks tied at the free ends of the string. Earlier in Spain, garroting was also an official method of execution of criminals.

An image of the execution of a prisoner by garroting is shown below

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation is defined as compression and strangulation with bare hands. 

Effects of pressure on the neck due to manual strangulation are:

  • Carotid artery blockage resulting in loss of consciousness
  • Carotid sinus pressure causing vagus nerve stimulation and cardiac arrest
  • Airway blockages causing hypoxemia 

The given autopsy images showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature mark point towards a diagnosis of throttling.

Option D: Smothering is defined as a form of asphyxia where the external respiratory orifices are closed either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance.

The image shows smothering, which involves the blockage of the external air passages, usually by a hand or soft fabric/pillow.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient complains of dull pain and stiffness in the lower back, which is maximum in the morning and improves with activity. He has had these symptoms for many years now. A radiograph of the spine was done and is shown below. Which of the following complications is unlikely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Limitations of the movements of the spine in all directions

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of early morning pain and stiffness in the lower back that improves with activity, along with the radiograph showing a bamboo spine appearance in the lumbar spine, are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Reduction or complete obliteration of the normal lumbar lordosis is seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

HLA-B27 is strongly linked to AS and it plays a direct role in the pathogenesis of the disease. The clinical features of AS first appear during late adolescence and early adulthood. The patients complain of early morning pain and stiffness in the lower back. The condition improves with activity and returns with inactivity. As the disease progresses, the pain becomes bilateral and persistent. 

On examination, there is restriction of all the movements of the lumbar spine (anterior and lateral flexion, and extension). Modified Schober test is done to measure lumbar spine flexion. In this test, the patient stands erect with the heels together, and two points are marked on the spine, as shown in the illustration below: one at the level of the lumbosacral junction (a horizontal line between the two posterosuperior iliac spines) and one 10 cm above this level. The patient is then asked to bend forward, and the distance between the two points is measured. This distance normally increases by ≥ 2 cm.

 

Other changes which are seen in the spine include obliteration of the lumbar lordosis, accentuated thoracic kyphosis, and restriction of the chest expansion. In advanced spinal disease, there is a high risk of spinal fracture (most often in the cervical region) due to osteoporosis and the spine being rigid. Such a fracture is mostly associated with spinal cord injury.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting. He was immediately given an intramuscular injection of a drug in 1:1000 dilution. The drug acts on which of the following receptor to improve the patient's breathing difficulty?
questions.solution:
The patient's complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting are suggestive of anaphylactic shock. The drug of choice for anaphylaxis is intramuscular adrenaline (0.5ml in 1:1000 dilution). Activation of beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation. Hence, adrenaline action on the beta 2 receptors improves the breathing difficulty in this patient. Apart from this, beta 2 receptors also inhibit the secretion from mast cells.

Other options:

Receptor Action Use in anaphylaxis treatment 
Alpha 1 and Alpha 2 Vasoconstriction Increase in BP
Beta 1 Cardiac stimulation Increase in BP
Beta 2 Bronchodilation Reverse bronchoconstriction 


The net effect of adrenaline on BP: Adrenaline rapidly increases blood pressure by reversing vasodilation and improving cardiac output. This is critical for preventing shock and ensuring adequate perfusion to vital organs during anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was diagnosed with AIDS and was started on antiretroviral drugs. After 10 months patient came to OPD and examination revealed hands as shown. The following change is encountered with the use of which of the following antiretroviral agents?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Nail hyperpigmentation which is commonly encountered with the use of zidovudine. This is seen with chronic zidovudine administration. 

The adverse effects of Zidovudine are:

  • Fatigue, malaise, myalgia, anorexia, headache, insomnia
  • Erythrocytic macrocytosis
  • Nail hyperpigmentation
  • Myopathy
  • Bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and granulocytopenia 

The image below shows zidovudine induced nail hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: 1 yr old boy presents with biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing and fever. Image given below depicts his Xray findings. All of the following are true about this condition except_____________

choices.text: Most common in age group of 6 months to 3 years
Most common organism responsible is Parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing, and fever in the child along with the steeple sign on x ray, is suggestive of croup or laryngotracheobronchitis. Biphasic stridor suggests subglottic involvement (not supraglottis).

Croup or laryngotracheobronchitis is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi caused by the parainfluenza virus (Option D). It is characterized by the subglottic swelling of loose areolar tissue leading to respiratory obstruction and stridor. It commonly affects children between 6 months and 3 years of age, more often male children. (Option A and B)

Laryngotracheobronchitis is characterized by a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Agitation and crying aggravate the symptoms and signs. A hoarse voice, coryza, normal to moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate can be revealed in the physical examination. The upper airway obstruction may progress and the child can present with an increased respiratory rate, nasal flaring; suprasternal, infrasternal, and intercostal retractions; and continuous stridor. On X-ray a Steeple/Church top/pencil top sign (obstruction in subglottis) is seen.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl has deliberately drunk phenol in an attempt to commit suicide. She complains of hot burning sensation extending from mouth to stomach. Which of the following statement is false regarding this?

choices.text: Methaemoglobinaemia is an associated feature in severe cases
It causes numbness by damaging the nerve endings
It is excreted in urine as hydroquinone and pyrocatechol

questions.solution:
Carbolic acid/Phenol is a corrosive acid, however, it hardens the GI mucosa producing a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. Gastric lavage is not contraindicated in phenol poisoning.

Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Local skin effects: Burning, tingling followed by anesthesia and greyish white sloughing 
  • Headache, giddiness, tinnitus
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, pain abdomen
  • Muscular spasms, convulsions
  • Collapse
  • A clammy, cold sweating body
  • Pupils contracted

In severe cases, hemolysis and methemoglobinemia are a characteristic feature.

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

In patients with acute poisoning, the stomach should be washed repeatedly. Initially with plenty of lukewarm water containing activated charcoal, olive oil, castor oil, magnesium or sodium sulphate, or saccharated lime with which phenol combines and forms harmless products. A soap solution or 10% glycerine may be used and the washing continued until the washings are clear and odorless.

Once the above is done, the administration of olive oil or vegetable oil is done to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. When lavage is completed, 30 g. of magnesium sulfate or a quantity of medicinal liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach.

questions.text: A 35-year-old wildlife photographer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia. On examination, you notice gingival bleeding and conjunctival hemorrhages. He recently visited a forest in Karnataka that has a large population of monkeys. What are the amplifier hosts, reservoirs, and incidental hosts respectively for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with exposure to monkeys, fever, myalgia, headache, conjunctival hemorrhage and gingival bleeds is suggestive of Kyasanur forest disease (KFD). Monkeys are amplifier hosts, rodents are reservoirs and humans are incidental hosts.

Kyasanur forest disease is an arboviral infection caused by a member of the virus family Flaviviridae. It is transmitted by ticks (Haemaphysalis spinigera) and is endemic to the forests of Karnataka and Kerala.

The clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Myalgia 
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hemorrhagic symptoms- hemorrhages in skin, mucosa and gastrointestinal bleeds.

The diagnosis is established via PCR, virus isolation from blood, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent serologic assay. A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.
